LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY

Borrower

The People’s Republic of China (PRC)

Project Description

The  Project  is  located  in  Liaoning  Province  and  involves  the
extension of the 500-kilovolt (kV) transmission system from north
to  south;  rehabilitation  of  220kV  electricity  transmission  networks
and urban and rural electricity distribution networks; closure of old
and  inefficient  coal-fired  power  generation  units;  and  support  for
reforms in the provincial power sector.

Classification

Thematic: Economic growth.

Environmental
Assessment

Rationale

Category B. An initial environmental examination was undertaken
and is included under the Supplementary Appendixes.

the 

interconnection  by  extending 

The  northeast  power  region  of  the  PRC  comprises  the  provinces
of  Jilin,  Heilongjiang,  and  Liaoning  and  the  Inner  Mongolia
Autonomous  Region.  Mine-mouth  coal-fired  power  generating
plants  are  located  in  the  sparsely  populated,  northern  Inner
Mongolia Autonomous Region, while the energy-consuming areas
are  mainly  in  the  industrial  south  of  Liaoning  Province.  Hence,
considerable  benefit  can  be  realized  by  interconnecting  the  north
and  the  south.  The  first  part  of  such  interconnection  from
Heilongjiang  Province  to  Shenyang  in  Liaoning  Province  was
completed  in  June  2001  under  a  1997  ADB  loan.1  The  proposed
the
Project  will  complete 
transmission  line  further  south.  The  Project  will  increase  the
capacity  and  efficiency  of  electricity  transmission  from  Shenyang
to  Dalian  in  Liaoning  Province,  thereby  increasing  the  availability
and reliability of electricity supply in the province. It will also result
in  an  integrated  regional  grid  that  will  facilitate  the  establishment
of  a  regional  competitive  power  market  as  envisaged  by  the
Government.  The  rural  poor  will  particularly  benefit  through  the
rehabilitation  of  rural  electrification  networks  in  three  poverty
counties  and  one  poverty  city,  which  will  decrease  the  costs  of
electricity  supply  to  these  areas  by  15–20  percent  through
efficiency  gains  and  will  enable  a  decrease  in  tariffs  for  rural
areas.  As  agreed  upon  under  the  Project’s  tariff  reform  action
plan,  the  tariffs  for  all  rural  areas  in  Liaoning  Province  will  be
reduced and brought in line with urban tariffs by December 2004.

The  principal  objective  of  the  Project  is  to  increase  the  capacity
and efficiency of electricity transmission from the northeastern part
of  the  PRC  to  the  southern  part  of  Liaoning  Province,  thereby
increasing  the  availability  of  electricity  and  the  reliability  of  the
electricity  transmission  and  distribution  systems  in  Liaoning

The  total  project  cost  is  estimated  at  $475  million  equivalent,
comprising  a  foreign  exchange  cost  of  $100  million  (21  percent)
and a local currency cost of $375 million equivalent (79 percent).

The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  provide  a  $100  million
loan  to  finance  the  entire  foreign  exchange  cost  of  the  Project.
The  remaining  local  currency  cost  of  $375  million  equivalent  will
be  financed  by  the  Executing  Agency’s  (EA)  internal  sources  of
$135  million  and  a  domestic  loan  of  $240  million  equivalent  from
the China Construction Bank.

ADB’s  $100 million  loan  from  ordinary  capital  resources  will
 have a repayment period of 24 years, including a grace period of
4 years,  with  interest  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s
London  Interbank  Overnight  Rate  (LIBOR)  based  lending  rate
system  for  US  dollar  loans,  a  front-end  fee  of  1  percent,  and  a
commitment charge of 0.75 percent per annum in accordance with
the  current  ADB  policy.  The  loan  proceeds  will  be  relent  by  the
Ministry of Finance to the EA through a subsidiary loan agreement
under the same terms and conditions.

Project Benefits
and Beneficiaries

Equipment, materials, and services financed from the proceeds of
the  ADB  loan  will  be  procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s
Guidelines for Procurement.  Items  financed  with  local  currency
funds  by  the  EA  will  be  procured  following  local  competitive
bidding  acceptable  to  ADB.  Advance  procurement  action  has
been approved by ADB.

International  consulting  services  for  30  person-months  will  be
provided to assist the EA with project implementation including its
review of the draft tender documents and its evaluation of the bids
received.  International  and  domestic  consulting  services  of  about
31 person-months will be provided for undertaking a power market
development  study.  All  consultants  will  be  selected  and  engaged
in  accordance  with  ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants
and  other  arrangements  for  the  selection  and  engagement  of
domestic consultants. Advance recruitment action and retroactive
financing of the consulting services have been approved by ADB.

The  Project will  improve  the efficiency and reliability of electricity
transmission  and  distribution  in  Liaoning  Province.  It  will  also
provide  environmental  and  health  benefits 
through  avoided
emissions from (i) obviating additional coal-fired power generation
that  would  otherwise  be  required  in  the  vicinity  of  Dalian  in  the
southern part of Liaoning Province; (ii) decreased use of firewood,
straw, and coal by poor households as a result of more affordable
electricity supply; and (iii) closure of inefficient and polluting coal-
fired power generation units.  Over its lifetime the Project will help
reduce and avoid emissions in the project area of about 324,600
tons  of  sulfur  dioxide,  164,600  tons  of  nitrogen  oxides,  215,100
tons of particulates, and 44.53 million tons of carbon dioxide. The
rural poor will particularly benefit through the rehabilitation of rural
electrification networks in three poverty counties and one poverty
city,  which  will  decrease  the  cost  of  electricity  supply  to  these
areas  by  15–20  percent  through  efficiency  gains,  which  will  be
shared with the rural residents including the rural poor in the form
of lower tariffs. The economic and financial internal rates of return
for  the  Project  are  satisfactory  at  18.5  percent  and  9.2  percent,
respectively.  The  Project’s  poverty  impact  ratio  is  estimated  at
17.3 percent. The envisaged decrease in rural tariffs to bring them
in line with urban tariffs will result in (i) increased consumption of
electricity in rural areas and (ii) household savings. In the medium
term  this  could  lead  to  an  increase  of  19.2  percent  in  per  capita
income for the rural poor in Liaoning Province between 2003 and
2007.  Further,  provision  of  energy-efficient  light  bulbs  to  about
100,000 poor households will reduce their electricity consumption
for lighting by about 30 percent.

I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  Report  and  Recommendation  on  a  proposed
loan  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Shen-Da  Power  Transmission  and  Grid
Rehabilitation Project.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL

II. 

INTRODUCTION

The PRC is the second largest electricity producer in the world after the United States.
2.
Coal accounts for about three quarters of the PRC’s thermal power generation. The continued
dominance  of  coal  in  power  generation  has  contributed  to  unacceptably  high  levels  of  air
pollution, resulting in health problems and increasing mortality rates, degenerating ecosystems,
decreasing crop yields, and increasing emissions of greenhouse gases and occurrences of acid
rain.  To  optimize  the  availability  and  use  of  generation  capacity  and  increase  the  efficiency  of
electricity  generation,  transmission,  and  distribution,  the  Government  is  upgrading  and
extending  power 
interregional
interconnections,  and  strengthening  urban  and  rural  distribution  systems.  This  will  help  to
reduce  the  use  of  coal  for  power  generation  and  develop  the  electricity  transmission  and
distribution infrastructure that is required for establishing competitive power generation markets.

transmission  systems,  particularly 

interprovincial  and 

During  the  1999  Country  Programming  Mission,  the  Government  requested  Asian
3.
Development Bank (ADB) assistance for providing a high-voltage transmission system between
the  cities  of  Shenyang  and  Dalian  in  Liaoning  Province  and  for  the  rehabilitation  of  electricity
distribution  systems  in  the  two  cities  and  the  surrounding  rural  areas.  In  response  to  this
request, in December 1999 ADB provided project preparatory technical assistance to examine
the  feasibility  of  the  Project.1  Following  completion  of  the  project  preparation  studies  in  March
2001, the Fact-Finding Mission visited the PRC in April 2001, followed by the Appraisal Mission
in June 2001, to discuss the Project with the Government and the Executing Agency (EA). The
linkages  of  the  policies,  institutional  framework,  physical  investments,  and  objectives  of  the
Project are described in the project framework (Appendix 1). The Project’s primary objective is
economic growth.

III. 

BACKGROUND

A. 

Sector Description

1.   

Energy Sector

4.
Annual  per  capita  energy  consumption  in  the  PRC  is  relatively  low  at  0.66  tons  of  oil
equivalent (toe) in 2000, about 40 percent of the world average. The energy intensity rate is still
quite  high,  about  0.78  toe  per  $1,000  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP),  or  roughly  twice  the
average for both ADB developing and developed member countries. Energy intensity declined
during the 1990s, when GDP grew by 9.7 percent per year and energy consumption grew at 2.3
percent per year. As a result, the energy intensity index2 dropped from 61.4 in 1990 to 30.3 in
2000, reflecting changes in economic structure and sources of industrial value added, as well as
energy  efficiency  improvements.  The  relatively  high  energy  and  intensity  index  is  mainly
attributable to (i) the  legacy  of  the  inappropriate pricing regime with inadequate market-based

                  

December 1999.

 2

signals  for  energy  conservation,  (ii) an  energy-intensive  industry  sector  that  accounts  for  a
relatively high share of GDP, (iii) a poor fuel consumption mix, (iv) the use of obsolete industrial
technologies, and (v) poor energy management.

2.

Power Sector

a.

General

By the end of 2000, the installed capacity was 316 gigawatts (GW) and annual electricity
5.
generation was 1,350  terawatt-hours (TWh). Thermal power contributes about three quarters of
the  installed  generating  capacity,  hydropower  about  one  quarter,  and  nuclear  power  about  1
percent.  Every  year  since  1988,  11–17  GW  of  generating  capacity  has  been  added.3  During
1985–1995, the annual average growth in electricity consumption was 9.1 percent. The growth
slowed  to  7.1  percent  in  1996  and  fell  to  4.4  in  1997  and  2.8  percent  in  1998.  However,
electricity consumption grew by 5.9 percent in 1999 and by 9.7 percent in 2000. The temporary
declines in electricity demand growth between 1997 and 1999 partly reflected the impact of the
Asian  economic  crisis  and  a  structural  shift  in  the  economy  that  moderated  the  growth  of
electricity consumption.

6.
The 2000 per capita annual electricity consumption of 1,064 kilowatt-hours (kWh) places
the PRC at the average level of per capita electricity consumption in ADB’s developing member
countries.4  Industries  consume  the  most  electricity.  Heavy  industry  consumed  58  percent,
followed  by  light  industry  (14 percent),  residential  consumers  (12   percent),  public  and
commercial  consumers  (8   percent),  agriculture  (6  percent),  and 
transportation  and
telecommunications (2 percent). Since 1985, the relative shares of industry and agriculture have
declined,  while  those  of  residential,  public,  and  commercial  consumers  have  increased.  About
98 percent  of  the  nation’s  villages  and  97  percent  of  the  rural  population  have  access  to
electricity, although the service is usually very inefficient and of uneven quality.

b.   

Pricing

7.
Electricity tariffs are set separately in each province. Tariff proposals are prepared jointly
by the provincial power companies and the provincial governments (mainly the provincial price
administration  bureaus)  and  submitted  to  the  Government  for  approval  by  the  State
Development  and  Planning  Commission.  Tariffs  generally  have  three  components:  (i) the
state  catalogue  price,  (ii)  guidance  price  differential,  and  (iii) surcharges.  The  state  catalogue
price is calculated to recover power generation costs, financed through government grants (all
plants built before 1985) and, in some cases, loans from the Government for plants built after
1985. Electricity is sold at a guidance price from power plants that have been financed through
joint  investments  by  central,  provincial,  and  local  governments;  plants  of  independent  power
producers; and plants that are owned by local governments or industries and sell surplus power
to the grid. This guidance price is based on full cost recovery including debt repayment and a
reasonable  return  on  investment.  Several  surcharges  are  levied  on  the  various  consumer
categories,  primarily  for  different  types  of  investment  funds  for  the  power  sector,  the  most
important  being  (i)  the  provincial  and  local  government  power  investment  surcharges,  which
raise  funds  for  special  projects  (e.g.,  for  the  Three  Gorges  project);  and  (ii)  local  fees  to  raise

 3

funds  for  distribution  system  investment.  Surcharges  usually  account  for  6–15  percent  of  the
average tariff.

8.
Before  1985,  electricity  tariffs  in  the  PRC  remained  at  a  relatively  low  level  for  many
years,  averaging  about  Y0.07  per  kWh.  Beginning  in  1985,  the  tariffs  were  increased  in
response  to  price  increases  in  fuel  and  other  capital  and  operating  costs.  However,  the  tariff
adjustments had several shortcomings, as a result of which tariff systems were complicated and
unfair  to  different  consumer  categories  and  to  similar  consumers  in  different  localities.  The
Government  considers  tariff  reform  to  be  of  primary  importance  for  the  development  of  the
power  industry.  Unification  of  tariffs  to  ensure  charging,  on  a  cost  recovery  basis,  the  same
price  for  the  same  quality  of  electricity  to  a  given  class  of  consumer  in  a  particular  grid  is  an
important objective. Since 1999, substantial progress has been made in tariff reform with regard
to  unification  of  end-consumer  tariff  at  the  provincial  level,  rationalization  of  consumer
categories to create a separate commercial tariff category, and elimination of surcharges.

9.
The  Government  is  using  a  combination  of  administrative  controls  and  market-based
reforms to improve energy end-use efficiency. The administrative measures include reductions
in planned allocations of energy to major industrial users; tightening energy consumption norms;
stricter application of such norms, with bonuses and penalties; and closing of inefficient plants.
At  present  the  Government  gives  priority  to  market-based  incentives,  including  price  reforms,
and  is  aiming  to  achieve  further  gains  in  energy  end-use  efficiency  through  implementing
structural  adjustments  in  the  industry  sector,  promoting  the  upgrading  of  technology,  and
strengthening energy management.

Transmission  tariffs  are  not  clearly  defined  in  the  PRC.  The  retail  tariffs  to  consumers
10.
are not adequate to provide a reasonable return on transmission and distribution infrastructure
and are not guided by principles of cost recovery, transparency, and nondiscrimination. A sound
methodology  to  determine  transmission  tariffs  needs  to  be  developed  to  eliminate  the  current
arbitrariness  in  levying  such  tariffs.  Although  the  problems  related  to  transmission  tariffs  are
minimal,  since  the  retail  tariffs  are  bundled,  the  transmission  pricing  method  needs  to  be
compatible with the power market design, which will be eventually introduced. The transmission
pricing that provides adequate financial returns and economic pricing signals is to be balanced
with social equity issues associated with the use of the transmission and distribution networks.

3.

Environment

The  PRC  has  severe  environmental  problems,  primarily  air  and  water  pollution
11.
associated  with  rapid  economic  growth  and  the  use  of  coal.    Estimates  of  economic  losses
caused  by  pollution  range  from  3.5–8.3 percent  of  GDP.  Based  on  a  study  by  the  Policy
Research  Center  for  Environment  and  Economy  of  the  State  Environmental  Protection
Administration, pollution in the early 1990s caused annual economic losses of Y99 billion (about
4 percent of GDP), with air pollution accounting for 59 percent; water pollution, 36 percent; and
solid waste, 5 percent.

The high economic losses reflect waste and inefficiency in the utilization of energy, raw
12.
materials, and other resources in the production of goods and services. This is partly a legacy of
the past practice of locating industrial enterprises in urban centers, and inappropriate regulatory
measures  and  pricing  policies  that  did  not  provide  adequate  incentives  for  conservation  and
environment-friendly behavior. Depending on the industry, 30–70 percent of industrial pollution
is  linked  to  waste  and  inefficiency  resulting  from  the  use  of  obsolete  technology,  inadequate
knowledge  of  available  cleaner  technology,  low  levels  of  environmental  awareness,  and  poor

 4

enterprise  management.  Use  of  energy  and  raw  materials  will  continue  to  grow  in  the  PRC  in
tandem with economic growth. Unless better technologies are used, switching to cleaner fuels is
encouraged,  and  use  of  renewable  energy  is  increased  in  a  major  way,  environmental  quality
will continue to deteriorate and related economic losses will increase.

and 

The  PRC's  heavy  reliance  on  coal  as  its  primary  fuel  for  industrial  production,  power

particulates (TSP), and high levels of urban air pollution. Air quality is poor in most of the PRC’s

14.
Emissions of major air pollutants peaked in 1995 and have declined since then. Airborne
concentrations  of  TSP,  SO2,  and  nitrogen  oxides  (NOx)  often  substantially  surpass
environmental standards.5 The social cost of this pollution is high. Over 400 million people live in
cities,  and  this  number  is  expected  to  double  by  2010.  Annual  premature  (compared  with  life
expectancy)  deaths  related  to  excessively  high  TSP  concentrations  are  currently  estimated  at
150,000  in  urban  areas.  Chronic  pulmonary  diseases  linked  to  TSP  exposure  are  a  leading
cause of death among urban residents, accounting for 9.1 deaths per 10,000 people, about five
times  more  than  in  the  United  States.  The  combustion  of  coal  in  small  boilers,  mainly  for
commercial and residential use, is responsible for a significant portion of total air pollution. To
combat air pollution from such sources, the Government gives priority to (i) developing district
heating systems to replace individual coal combustion for residential heating; (ii) developing gas
supply  networks  to  replace  coal  combustion  with  a  cleaner  form  of  energy  for  household
cooking  and,  in  some  instances,  heating;  (iii)  introducing  clean  coal  technologies  and  other
environment-friendly technologies for power generation; and (iv) developing mine-mouth, coal-
fired  power  plants.  The  introduction  of  advanced  clean  coal  technologies  such  as  pressurized
fluidized  bed  combustion  and  integrated  coal  gasification  combined-cycle  technology  is  being
considered.6  In  April  2000,  the  Prevention  of  Air  Pollution  Law  was  amended,  enabling  the
Government  to  take  effective  measures  to  encourage  and  support  scientific  research  and
technology  development  for  the  prevention  and  control  of  air  pollution.7  Implementation  of  the
law began in September 2000.

4.   

Institutions and Legal Framework

15.
During  the  past  decade,  the  Government  reorganized  the  energy  sector.  The  objective
was  to  improve  governance  by  separating  regulatory  and  operating  responsibilities,  and  then
corporatizing the operating entities and using market forces to improve efficiency and promote
energy conservation. First, the Ministry of Energy was disbanded and replaced with the Ministry
of  Electric  Power  (MEP);  the  Ministry  of  Coal  Industry;  and  two  corporations  looking  after
petroleum  and  natural  gas.  Subsequent  administrative  reforms  aimed  at  improving  the
operational efficiency of the power industry led to MEP restructuring with the establishment of
the State Power Corporation (SP) in January 1997. In March 1998, MEP was abolished and SP
was designated as the agency responsible for power sector enterprise functions.8 The sector’s
regulatory  and  policy  functions  are  the  responsibility  of  the  State  Economic  and  Trade
Commission, which has similar responsibility for the petroleum and coal sectors, as well as the
country’s energy conservation program. Until the mid-1990s, the power sector was governed by
laws,  administrative  rules  and  regulations,  and  policy  circulars  that  were  not  well  coordinated.
To address this problem, the Electric Power Law was approved in December 1995 and became
effective in April 1996. This law was a major step in making the legal and regulatory framework
for the sector more transparent.9

B.    Government Policies and Plans

1.   

Poverty Reduction Strategy

16.
The  Government  is  making  major  efforts  to  reduce  the  imbalance  in  economic
development between the increasingly prosperous coastal provinces and the poorer central and
western  regions.  In  the  PRC,  poverty  has  largely  been  a  rural  phenomenon.  By  pursuing  a
strategy  to  raise  living  standards  and  incomes  in  the  poorer  rural  areas  through  Government
investments  and  subsidies  in  land  development,  rural  works,  rural  energy  supply,  and  rural
enterprises, the PRC has made commendable progress in reducing absolute rural poverty from
260 million in 1978 to 30 million in 2001 using the PRC definition of rural poverty.10 In the power
sector the Government is planning to establish more coal-fired power plants in the central and
western  regions  to  create  economic  activity  and  jobs  and  export  the  power  to  the  coastal
regions,  which  will  require  the  construction  of  additional  transmission  lines.  Since  1997,  there
has  been  growing  concern  about  urban  poverty  in  the  PRC.  This  reflects  growing  urban
unemployment  brought  about  by  industrial  enterprise  reforms  and  government  downsizing,  in
particular, retrenchment of excess employees of state-owned enterprises (SOEs). By the end of
2000 there were about 6 million unemployed workers and about 6.5 million laid-off workers who
became  unemployed.  Around  600  cities  and  1,200  counties  have  established  programs  to
ensure minimum living expenses. ADB TA has been provided to the Government for developing
an  analytical  framework  for  addressing  the  increasing  urban  poverty.11  Since  1995,  ADB  has
been providing TAs for the development of the Government’s Social Security Reform Program,
which  aims  to  improve  the  income  security  for  pensioners  and  the  institutional  capacity  and

administrative  efficiency  of  the  social  safety  net  to  protect  both  urban  and  rural  poor  who  are
unemployed and need some minimum income support.12

17. 
To  coordinate  poverty  reduction  efforts  in  rural  areas,  poverty  reduction  offices  have
been  established  at  the  provincial,  municipal,  and  county  levels.  Over  the  past  two  decades
central,  provincial,  municipal,  and  county  governments  have  been  providing  subsidies,
investments,  and  other  assistance  to  poverty  counties  such  as  direct  financial  support,
microcredit, building materials, livestock, and seeds, which has helped raise the average annual
per capita income in the national poverty counties from Y206 in 1985 to Y1,347 in 1999. During
1994-2000 this was implemented under the Government’s National 8-7 Poverty Reduction Plan,
which aimed to enable the 80 million absolute rural poor, using the PRC definition ( footnote 10),
to meet their basic human needs within seven years. As a result, the number of such absolute
rural poor had decreased to about 30 million in 2001.

18.
In  Liaoning  Province,  the  provincial,  municipal,  and  county  governments  provide  about
Y50 million a year for poverty reduction in the nine national poverty counties. In addition, poor
households in these poverty counties and the two provincial poverty counties receive about Y8
million a year in microcredit funds. Provincial, municipal, and county governments allocate these
microcredit  funds  from  their  fiscal  revenues.  The  microcredit  funds  are  provided  mainly  to
women’s  groups,  which  use  them  for  animal  breeding  (such  as  geese),  crop  planting,
construction of greenhouses, and processing of agricultural products. 

2.

Energy Sector Strategy

One of the Government’s main objectives for energy sector development up to 2020 is to
19.
reduce the growth of coal consumption and the environmental pollution that such consumption
causes. The Government is promoting (i) the introduction of clean coal technologies throughout
the  entire  process  of  coal  production,  handling,  transportation,  and  consumption;  (ii) where
possible,  substitution  of  coal  by  natural  gas,  hydropower,  and  renewable  energy;  and  (iii)
demand-side  management  to  decrease  the  growth  rate  in  energy  consumption.13  Under  its
Tenth  Five-Year  Plan  (TFYP),  2001-2005,  the  Government  is  planning  to  accelerate,  in
particular, the development and utilization of natural gas. For this purpose the  Government is
planning  to  undertake  (together  with  private  investors)  major  gas  infrastructure  projects,
including  the  construction  of  (i)  long  distance  transmission  pipelines  to  transport  natural  gas
from known gas fields in the western part of the country to the coastal provinces in the east,14

The  Government  will  develop  renewable  energy  to  (i) diversify  power  generation,  (ii)
20.
accelerate rural development, (iii) develop sustainable resources, and (iv) derive environmental
benefits.  However,  compared  with  the  available  potential,  the  PRC's  renewable  energy
program  is  relatively  small.  At  present,  only  about  18.7  GW  of  renewable  energy  capacity
(mostly  in  the  form  of  small  hydropower  plants)  has  been  harnessed  out  of  an  estimated
potential  of  more  than  350 GW.  The  Government’s  Program  on  New  and  Renewable  Energy
Development  (1996-2010)  aims  to  improve  the  efficiency  of  renewable  energy  technologies,
reduce  production  costs,  and  increase  the  use  of  renewable  energy.  Among  other  things,  it
targets  a  cumulative  capacity  of  400  megawatts  (MW)  of  grid-connected  wind  farms  by  2000,
and 1,500 MW by 2010. Although the target for 2000 has not been met, with only about 265 MW
of  grid-connected  wind  farms  by  the  end  of  2000,  that  for  2010  will  most  likely  be  surpassed,
given  the  measures  contemplated  by  the  Government.16  During  the  TFYP,  the  Government
intends to gradually introduce the requirement that a certain share of the electricity supplied to
consumers  be  generated  from  renewable  energy  resources,  thus  maintaining  their  present
share  in  the  generation  mix.  Initially  this  would  be  introduced  at  the  national  level,  and
subsequently  passed  on  to  provincial  electricity  grid  levels.  About  18 GW  of  new  renewable
energy  capacity  would  need  to  be  added  until  2010  to  achieve  this  target.  Such  a  policy  will
create  a  secure  long-term  market  for  renewable  energy  resources,  attractive  to  investors.17
Support  for  the  development  of  grid-connected  wind  farms  and  increased  use  of  wind-based
electricity was provided by ADB with cofinancing from the Global Environment Facility (GEF).18
In 2001, the World Bank and GEF are planning to provide support under their China renewable
energy scale-up project for the implementation of a national policy framework that would legally
require  a  certain  share  of  electricity  supply  to  be  met  from  renewable  resources.19  However,
several  more  years  will  likely  be  required  before  the  appropriate  regulatory  and  policy
framework  is  established  to  meet  a  portfolio  standard  that  a  certain  share  of  the  electricity
generated is produced from renewable energy.

north, the middle, and the south of the country to transfer electricity from the west to the east;22
(ii) establishing mine-mouth coal-fired power plants; (iii) rehabilitating urban and rural electricity

west; (vi) restructuring and deregulating23 the power sector; and (vii) effecting tariff reform. The

for restructuring the power sector, which will aim at increasing efficiency in the sector through

before the end of 2001. ADB's operations in the PRC will support the Government’s agenda for

4. 

Environmental Strategy

22.
The Government's environment sector objectives are to (i) bring environmental pollution
under control, (ii) improve the quality of the environment in major cities, (iii) reduce degradation
of  natural  ecological  systems,  and  (iv)  integrate  environmental  planning  with  economic  and
social  development  efforts.  Under  the  NFYP  the  Government's  main  environmental  objective
was  to  arrest  degradation  in  the  environment  by  improving  air  and  water  quality  in  52  major
cities  where  pollution  is  most  severe.  The  basic  policies  and  guiding  principles  included
pursuing  a  strategy  of  sustainable  development  by  integrating  environmental  protection
programs 
into  national  economic  and  social  planning,  and  establishing  an  effective
environmental  regulatory  framework  and  management  systems  in  both  urban  and  rural  areas.
The  aim  was  to  contain  the  worsening  trend  of  environmental  pollution  and  ecosystem
degradation, and to improve the environment in some cities to demonstrate that rapid economic
growth  and  a  cleaner  environment  are  compatible.  To  achieve  these  objectives,  the
Government  aimed  to  increase  annual  environment-related  investments  from  0.67  percent  of
GDP during the Seventh Five-Year Plan (1986-1990) to 1.3 percent during the NFYP. Although

this target was not achieved, environment-related investments increased substantially and were

23.
Under  the  TFYP,  the  Government  is  planning  to  strengthen  its  control  of  pollutant
discharge  through  the  issuance  of  regulations  on  total  pollutant  control  for  selected  cities  and
designated  river  basins  and  regions.  Ecological  protection  will  be  given  importance  equal  to
pollution  control,  and  environmental  protection  of  agriculture  will  be  strengthened.  Sustainable
urban development will be strengthened through the construction of centralized heating systems
and  sewage  and  solid  waste  treatment  plants  in  large  and  medium-sized  cities.  Air  quality  in
cities  is  to  be  improved  through  the  substitution  of  gas  for  coal  where  feasible,  modernization
and  closing  of  polluting  industries,  and  increased  use  of  technologies  and  fuels  that  minimize
pollution  from  vehicular  emissions.  Also,  automated  air  quality  monitoring  networks  will  be
established in large and medium-sized cities, and continuous monitoring of water quality along
stretches  of  several  major  rivers  will  begin.  To  achieve  these  objectives,  the  Government  will
strengthen  institutional  and  regulatory  frameworks  and  increasingly  introduce  market-based
instruments  for  effective  environmental  management.  To  enhance  the  use  of  market-based
instruments  for  air  quality  management  in  Shanxi  Province  and  strengthen  the  required
institutional  capabilities  of  the  concerned  provincial  agencies,  ADB  is  providing  TA,24  which  is
being  implemented  and  expected  to  be  completed  by  the  middle  of  2002.  In  this  context,  the
Government  is  also  planning  to  prepare  and  promulgate  a  law  on  environmental  impact
assessment,  which  will  require  that  strategic  environment  assessments  be  made  for  all
proposed national planning and policy development activities, and that possible environmental
impacts  be  fully  integrated  in  the  decision-making  process.  The  Government’s  overall  goal  for
improving air quality is to reduce SO2 emissions in acid rain and SO2 control zones by 2005 by
20  percent  below  their  2000  levels  and  by  10  percent  on  average  for  the  whole  of  the  PRC.
About  75  percent  of  the  power  generation  capacity  in  the  PRC  uses  fossil  fuels,  and  power
generation is responsible for about 40 percent of air pollution. Under its TFYP, the Government
is  planning  to  make  annual  environment-related  investments  of  1.3  percent  of  GDP,  which
would total about Y360 billion.

C.  External Assistance to the Sector

24.
Because of the energy sector’s importance for the national economy, it has been one of
the  largest  recipients  of  capital  and  advanced  technology,  financed  from  multilateral  and
bilateral  sources.  External  sources,  including  direct  foreign  investment,  are  increasingly  being
promoted  and  now  finance  about  20  percent  of  total  annual  investments  in  the  energy  sector,
which are used mainly in the power sector.

ADB has provided 10 public sector loans totalling $1.2 billion for the PRC power sector.
25.
These include three hydropower, four thermal power, and two power transmission projects, and
one renewable energy (grid-connected wind power) project. ADB has made strategic use of TA
to help prepare projects, provide policy support, and build the institutional capabilities of power
utilities that are the EAs of ADB loans. Among external agencies, ADB has taken a leading role
in providing support for (i) corporatizing power utilities, (ii) developing the policy and regulatory
frameworks for encouraging foreign investment in the power sector, (iii) introducing competitive
bidding procedures for the selection of build-own-operate and build-own-transfer sponsors, (iv)

24 TA 3325-PRC: Shanxi Air Quality Improvement, for $700,000, approved on 7 December 1999.

                  

 10

strengthening  financial  management  of  power  plants,  and  (v)  rationalizing  the  power  tariff
structure.

26.
The World Bank is the largest official source of external funding for the power sector. As
of April 2001, it had provided $5.6 billion to finance 23 power projects, most of which are large-
scale  thermal  power  or  hydropower  projects.  Under  its  2001  program,  the  World  Bank  is
planning to support two power projects: one pump storage project in Jiangsu Province and one
small hydropower project in Hubei Province. Its future program is expected to focus mainly on
renewable  energy  projects  under  the  World  Bank-GEF  Strategic  Partnership  for  Renewables
(footnote 19). Recently, the World Bank’s TA for the power sector has been mainly supporting
the  Government’s  efforts  to  design  and  implement  detailed  regulatory  procedures  for
deregulation of the power sector. The United Nations Development Programme is also providing
assistance to help the Government evaluate various options for power sector restructuring and
for promoting energy conservation (footnote 13).

27.
Among the bilateral sources, the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC) is the
largest  source  of  external  assistance.  It  has  provided  concessional  loans  totaling  Y438  billion
($3.6  billion  at  the  current  exchange  rate)  for  14  power  sector  projects  through  its  official
development  assistance  window,  excluding  those  assisted  through  export  credits  and  untied
yen  loans  which  were  provided  by  the  former  Export-Import  Bank  of  Japan.  JBIC  has  also
provided  special  credits  to  major  cities,  including  Dalian  and  Shenyang,  to  improve  their
environment through the installation of emission control devices and equipment in power plants
and  factories,  and  through  building  water  treatment  facilities.  JBIC  is  considering  shifting  its
traditional focus of assistance to the power sector from hydro and thermal power generation to
energy  conservation  and  renewable  energy,  particularly  in  the  western  region.  Germany,
through  the  Kreditanstalt  für  Wiederaufbau  (KfW),  has  provided  approximately  $400  million  in
mixed  credits  mostly  for  power  plants  and  turbine  modernization  projects.  KfW  has  been  also
assisting  the  Government  in  energy  efficiency,  providing  credit  lines,  and  renewable  energy
development. Other bilateral sources, mostly providing export credits, or mixed credits include
Australia, Canada, Denmark, France, Italy, Spain, United Kingdom, and United States.

28. While the huge investment requirements of the PRC’s power sector and the large size of
the country provide ample opportunities for the involvement of multiple aid agencies without the
risk  of  overlapping  investment,  aid  coordination  among  external  agencies  remains  essential.
ADB  has  established  a  close  working  relationship  with  the  World  Bank  in  addressing  policy
issues  and  coordinating  lending  and  TA  operations,  and  continues  to  exchange  views  with
bilateral  sources  and  the  private  sector.  Both  ADB  and  the  World  Bank  have  emphasized  the

D. 

Lessons Learned

29.
ADB’s experience in the PRC’s energy sector has shown that projects are generally well
planned and implemented smoothly. EAs and implementing agencies have personnel with good
technical skills and have made effective use of the training financed under ADB loans to build
their institutional capacity. Compliance with covenants is generally acceptable, although greater
efforts  are  required  to  implement  the  policy-related  covenants,  particularly  those  relating  to
diversification  of  enterprise  ownership  at  the  micro  level  in  line  with  project  commitments  and

 11

policy  directions.  The  rigorous  government  screening  of  the  projects  has  a  positive  impact.
Energy conservation projects have experienced some delays, mainly because of their complex
multicomponent  nature  involving  several  implementing  agencies  in  different  provinces.  Delays
have  also  occurred  for  some  projects  in  loan  signing  and  loan  effectiveness,  as  well  as  in
procurement,  construction,  and  commissioning.  The  Government  is  streamlining  the  multiple
approval process to address these problems.

30.
Power  utilities  have  been  found  to  be  weak  in  the  area  of  commercial  and  financial
management. Often, there is a need for institutional strengthening in the areas of organizational
structure,  delegation  of  authority,  management,  information  and  control  systems,  accounting
and  financial  management,  and  personnel  development  and  training.  So  far,  4  of  10  public
power  sector  projects  financed  by  ADB  in  the  PRC  have  been  completed;  these  are  the  Fuel
Conversion Project,25 Shanxi Liulin Thermal Power Project,26 Hunan Lingjintan Power Project,27
and  Henan  Power  Project.28  The  project  completion  and  project  performance  audit  reports  for
these projects indicate that they were implemented smoothly, and assess them all as generally
successful. Some cost increases as well as minor delays were noted. Recommendations from
the experience gained highlight (i) the need to improve financial reporting; (ii) the need for more
attention  to  environmental  matters;  (iii)  the  advisability  of  using  larger  boiler-turbine  units;  and
(iv) the importance of capacity building, not only for project preparation, but also for training staff
in  operational  and  managerial  aspects  of  power  utility  operations.  A  reevaluation  of  the  Fuel
Conversion  Project,  which  was  completed  in  December  1999,  revised  the  project  rating
downward to unsuccessful in economic terms and concludes that ADB-financed projects in the
energy  sector  should  not  be  narrowly  focused  on  expected  economic  gains,  which  may  not
materialize, and should be rigorously screened to ensure that they are in line with ADB’s energy
policy.29  Recently,  some  ongoing  power  projects  in  the  PRC  have  experienced  some
implementation delays in meeting procurement and construction deadlines. This is mainly due
to the ongoing restructuring of the power sector and consequent change in the ownership of the
projects. Nevertheless, the overall implementation performance of ADB’s energy portfolio in the
PRC is satisfactory.30

31.
The  above  lessons  have  been  taken  into  account  in  designing  the  Project.  A
comprehensive  feasibility  study  was  prepared  for  it,  and  consulting  services  committed  their
respective  loans,  which  have  been  secured  through  guarantees  from  will  be  provided  to
assist  with  project  implementation.  Domestic  commercial  banks  have  relevant  provincial
government agencies. Local currency financing was structured to ensure an appropriate mix of
debt and Government equity. Provision was made for sufficient working capital, and sensitivity
analysis of financial and economic performance was undertaken.

In  the  energy  sector,  ADB's  operational  strategy  supports  the  Government's  two-pronged

33.
ADB’s  energy  sector  operations  in  the  PRC  focus  on  (i)  supporting  improvements  in
transmission  and  distribution  systems  to  promote  system-wide  efficiency  and  reduce  losses,
including improvement of the reliability and affordability of rural electricity supply; (ii) developing
cleaner  energy  sources  such  as  hydropower,  clean  coal  technologies,  natural  gas,  methane
gas,  and  renewable  energy;  (iii) renovating  and  retrofitting  existing  facilities  to  improve
efficiency and reduce emissions; (iv) promoting the corporatization and commercialization of
power utilities; (v) sector restructuring; and (vi) pricing and tariff reforms. This is complemented
by  ADB's  strategy  for  the  environment  sector,  which  focuses  on  (i) strengthening  the  legal,
policy, and regulatory framework for sustainable environmental management; (ii) supporting
institutional building programs in environmental monitoring and enforcement; (iii) supporting the
utilization  of  economic,  supply-side,  and  other  measures  to  ensure  sustainable  utilization  of
natural  resources;  (iv)  promoting  the  use  of  cleaner  technologies  for  industrial  production;
(v) promoting market-based  pricing  and  encouraging  cost  recovery;  and  (vi)  implementing  and
monitoring agro-industrial pollution control mechanisms.

ADB's poverty reduction strategy for the PRC envisages a range of measures: (i) in the
34.
short  term,  providing  goods  and  services  directly  to  the  most  vulnerable  members  of  society;
(ii) in the medium term, improving health, education, and social security systems by supporting
institutional reform and capacity building; and (iii) in the long term, promoting sustainable, pro-
poor  growth  by  improving  infrastructure  and  creating  jobs  in  areas  with  a  high  incidence  of
poverty.  Since  the  PRC  does  not  have  access  to  Asian  Development  Fund  resources,  it  has
been  reluctant  to  borrow  for  projects  that  address  short-  and  medium-term  poverty  reduction
measures.  Therefore,  most  of  ADB’s  poverty-related  activities  will  tackle  the  following:  (i)
providing  the  necessary  physical  infrastructure  in  the  poorer  interior  provinces,  particularly  in
poverty  counties,  to  stimulate  economic  growth;  (ii) designing  infrastructure  projects  to  more
broadly distribute project benefits in poor areas; (iii) encouraging natural resource management
to sustain agricultural production of poor areas, and targeting agriculture and rural development
projects towards the poor; (iv) supporting social security reform and the development of a social
safety net to offset the social costs related to SOE reform and ameliorate the increasing urban
poverty;  (v)  ensuring  that  affordability  by  income  level  is  considered  during  policy  dialogue
related  to  cost  recovery  (e.g., lifeline  tariffs);  (vi)  ensuring  that  resettlement  requirements  of

In line with Energy 2000, Review of the Energy Policy of the Asian Development Bank,
35.
ADB's  assistance  in  the  PRC’s  energy  sector  will  be  aligned  with  the  three  pillars  of  ADB's
poverty reduction strategy, i.e., pro-poor sustainable economic growth, social development, and
good governance. Energy projects will be formulated and designed to support pro-poor growth,

F.   

Policy Dialogue

1.   

Tariff Reform

36.
The Government considers tariff reforms crucial for (i) developing multichannel financing
sources,  (ii)  promoting  investments  by  independent  power  producers,  (iii)  establishing  fair
competition  among  power  utilities,  and  (iv)  providing  incentives  to  improve  efficiency  and
encourage energy conservation. The objectives of the ongoing tariff reforms include (i) charging
the  same  price  for  the  same  quality  of  supply  in  each  grid  (producer  prices),  (ii)  adopting  the
same  end-consumer  tariff  for  the  same  categories  of  consumers  in  each  province,  and  (iii)
establishing a transparent tariff management system.

37.
ADB  is  emphasizing  the  importance  of  tariff  reforms  to  ensure  the  economic  efficiency
and  the  financial  sustainability  of  power  utilities,  secure  adequate  financing  for  system
expansion,  encourage  efficient  use  of  energy,  and  attract  private  sector  investment.  The
Government accepts the principle of full cost recovery in pricing electricity. In processing power
projects  in  the  provinces  of  Hunan,  Henan,  Yunnan,  and  Fujian,  and  in  the  northeast  power
region,  ADB  has  ensured,  through  policy  dialogue  with  the  Government,  that  satisfactory  tariff
reforms are being applied progressively in the concerned project areas. Progress in achieving a
more  rational  tariff  structure  at  the  provincial  level  is  expected  to  gradually  lead  to  nationwide
improvements.  During  project  processing,  it  was  agreed  to  advance  tariff  reforms  in  Liaoning
Province, and a tariff reform action plan was agreed to for this purpose. The associated reforms
will  focus  on  (i)  rationalizing  the  classification  of  consumer  categories;  (ii)  eliminating  all  local
surcharges; (iii) making adequate upward adjustments from the current tariff level to reflect the
long-run marginal cost (LRMC) of power supply at different voltage levels, loads, times of day,
and  seasons;  (iv)  making  electricity  more  affordable  for  rural  consumers  by  gradually
decreasing rural tariffs to bring them in line with corresponding urban tariffs by December 2004,
which  will  be  beneficial  for  the  rural  poor;  and  (v)  developing  transmission  tariffs.    Under  the
Project, the Government has agreed to (i) overall tariff increases for the Liaoning Electric Power
Company  Ltd.  (LEPC)  to  better  reflect  its  LRMC  of  power  supply  at  different  voltage  levels,
loads, times of day, and seasons,32 (ii) sharing the efficiency gains in the supply of electricity to

32 Includes improvement of the two-part tariff system, which comprises a fixed capacity charge and a variable energy

                  

charge.

rural  areas  with  rural  consumers  by  lowering  their  tariffs,33  (iii)  further  rationalization  of  the
classification  of  consumer  categories,34  and  (iv)  development  of  a  transmission  tariff
methodology. The tariff reform action plan is supported at the provincial level by LEPC and the
Liaoning  Pricing  Bureau,  and  at  the  national  level  by  SDPC  and  SP.  Appendix  2  provides  a
detailed  description  of  the  existing  electricity  tariffs  in  Liaoning  Province  and  the  tariff  reform
action plan.

2.  Restructuring of the Power Sector

38.
The existing legal and regulatory framework in the PRC is not adequate to support the
establishment  of  a  wholesale  market  for  power  generation.  This  reflects  deficiencies  in  the
existing  commercial  law  and  contract  law,  and  an  inadequate  competition  policy  in  the  PRC.
Following  the  recommendations  developed  under  an  ADB  TA  for  power  sector  restructuring
(footnote 23), which was considered at the highest levels of the Government, it is proposed that
a  uniform  wholesale  market  design  be  adopted  throughout  the  PRC  that  would  be  based  on
regional  wholesale  markets  for  each  grid,  with  transmission  pricing  based  on  cost  of
transmission, and would have the following key features.

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

Suppliers (thermal, hydro, and captive generation) and customers (large buyers
and  retailers)  agree  on  price  and  quantities  through  bids  and  offers  in  a
wholesale market.

The  wholesale  market  operates  across  provinces  and  is  operated  by  a  single
regional market and system operator.

Financial  contracts  for  differences35  are  to  be  used  for  risk  management  and  to
replace existing power purchase agreements.

Eventually, real time power flows and allocation of transmission capacity will be
determined based on offers and bids of generators and retailers.

39.
Until  now,  the  PRC  has  focused  on  introducing  power  sector  reforms  in  certain
provinces.  Liaoning  Province  is  one  of  the  pilot  areas  where  power  sector  reforms  have  been
introduced  with  some  success.  The  separation  of  LEPC’s  power  generation  activities  from  its
power  transmission  activities  is  ongoing,  and  currently,  nongovernment  investors  own  a  small
proportion  of  generation  assets  within  Liaoning  Province.  ADB,  in  its  policy  dialogue,  has
emphasized that at this stage of power sector reforms, a national strategy should be developed
for power sector reform in terms of industry structure, wholesale market design, and regulation
of  competition  and  network  pricing.  This  shift  to  a  national  approach  will  ensure  that  the
maximum  benefits  of  competition  in  a  deregulated  power  market  are  realized  through  an
optimum  national  allocation  of  Government  resources.  This  would  also  facilitate  the  linkage  of
regional power markets through common trading agreements, as each region is interconnected
as  part  of  a  national  grid  development  plan.  The  recommended  approach  is  to  (i)  restructure
provincial power companies, including the incorporation of power distribution companies, (ii) set
zonal  transmission  prices,  (iii)  establish  regional  market  operators  and  system  operators,  (iv)

40. With regard to LEPC’s further restructuring in anticipation of a wholesale power market

3.

Maximizing the Project’s Impact on the Poor

41.     The tariff reform action plan (para. 37) will, among others, reduce the electricity tariffs in
rural areas and make electricity more affordable for the rural poor in Liaoning Province. This will
result  in  an  average  increase  in  per  capita  income  of  the  rural  poor  of  about  19.2  percent
between 2003 and 2007. The increase in electricity consumption in the rural areas of Liaoning
Province  is  expected  to  lead  to  an  average  increase  of  the  annual  per  capita  income  of  Y23.
The increase in electricity consumption could lead to a 2.3 percent annual increase in the per
capita  income  for  the  rural  poor  who  have  an  annual  per  capita  income  of  not  more  than
Y1,000.37  Based  on  LEPC’s  projections  for  rural  electricity  consumption,  the  cost  savings  for
households as a result of the proposed tariff reforms would be about Y16.8 billion between 2003
and 2007. If such savings are used for investments in productive activities, this could lead to an
average  increase  in  annual  per  capita  income  of  Y77  in  the  rural  areas  over  a  period  of  five
years. This would imply an average increase in per capita income of 7.7 percent between 2003
and 2007 for the rural poor. Together, these two impacts could lead to an increase of about 19.2
percent in the average per capita income of the rural poor in Liaoning Province between 2003
and 2007.

42.
  As  a  result  of  ADB’s  policy  dialogue,  it  was  agreed  that  LEPC,  in  consultation  with

lighting  and  cooking  more  affordable  for  the  poor.38  Lifeline  tariffs  are  not  being  used  in  the
PRC, and their introduction in Liaoning Province will have national implications in demonstrating
how electricity tariffs can be designed to be pro-poor. To spread the benefits of the Project more

A. 

Rationale

IV. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

43.
The northeast power region extends over Heilongjiang, Jilin, and Liaoning provinces and
the eastern part of the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The long-term power development
plan for this power system envisages the construction of large mine-mouth power plants in the
coal-rich Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region and Heilongjiang Province, and transferring power
in bulk to the power-deficient southern parts of the region using high-voltage transmission lines.
Implementation of this plan will result in (i) environmental benefits resulting from moving thermal
power  generation  outside  densely  populated  urban  areas;  (ii)  job  creation  in  mining,  power
generation,  and  ancillary  services;  and  (iii)  increased  economic  productivity,  since  it  is
economically  more  efficient  to  transmit  power  than  to  transport  coal.  Originally,  power  flowed
from  the  north  to  the  south  through  a  single-circuit  500  kilovolt  (kV)  transmission  line  from
Harbin to Liaoning Province, as well as 220 kV tie lines between Heilongjiang and Jilin, and Jilin
and Liaoning provinces. Since the power transmission capability of these lines was limited, ADB
provided a loan for construction of another single-circuit, 500 kV transmission line of 724 circuit
kilometers  (km)  from  Yongyuan  near  Harbin  in  Heilongjiang  Province  to  Shenyang  and
Liaoyang in Liaoning Province including substation and communication systems.41 This project
was successfully completed according to schedule in June 2001.

44.
The  power  demand  growth  of  Liaoning  Province  is  the  highest  in  the  northeast  region.
The  annual  average  power  consumption  growth  rate  for  the  province  was  4.5  percent  during
1990–1999.  By  2005,  a  1,150  MW  power  deficiency  is  projected  for  the  southern  part  of
Liaoning  Province,  and  additional  power  generation  capacity  will  need  to  be  installed  in  the
southern part of Liaoning Province, if no additional power can be supplied from the north to this
part  of  the  province.  The  Project  will  meet  this  deficit  by  providing  a  high-voltage  power
transmission system, enabling the transfer of power from the northern part of the region, which
has  a  surplus  of  power,  to  the  southern  part  of  Liaoning  Province.  The  Project  will  therefore

                  

39 The savings are based on the use of one compact fluorescent with a capacity of 13 watts and one ordinary light

bulb of 40 watts for approximately five hours per day.

40 Under the existing organization structure LEPC is also wholly owned by SP.
41 Loan 1582-PRC: Northeast Power Transmission Project, for $150 million, approved on 25 November 1997.

 17

eliminate the need for installation in the near future of new coal-fired power generation capacity
in  the  densely  populated  southern  part  of  Liaoning  Province,  thereby  avoiding  additional  coal
transport and the harmful emissions associated with additional coal-fired power generation. The
Project  will  also  upgrade  the  transmission  system  around  Shenyang  by  adding  the  west-side
loop and establishing a 500 kV ring system. This will increase by optimizing the loading of the
220 kV system, which will decrease transmission losses and increase electricity reliability in the
Shenyang region.

The  upgrading  and  expansion  of  rural  electrification  in  three  poverty  counties  and  one
45.
poverty city, which will complete such upgrading and expansion in the relatively poor rural areas
of  Liaoning  Province,  increase  the  availability  and  reliability  of  electricity  supply,  and  reduce
system  losses  and  the  costs  of  supply  to  these  areas  by  15–20  percent.  At  present,  the  rural
people  in  these  poverty  areas  use  a  combination  of  straw,  firewood,  and  coal  to  meet  their
energy requirements. In 2000, it was found that, depending on the area, 70–90 percent of the
inhabitants  reported  suffering  from  eye  and  throat  irritations.  Surveys  of  beneficiaries  also
confirmed  that  rural  households  in  the  concerned  areas  would  begin  substituting  electricity  for
straw,  firewood,  and  coal  for  electricity  if  the  cost  of  electricity  decreased  and  the  electrical
supply became more reliable as is envisaged under the tariff reform action plan. The Project will
also  increase  productivity  and  result  in  more  efficient  power  generation  in  Liaoning  Province,
since the reinforced transmission network will allow for a reduction of the idle generating reserve
margins of existing power plants in the region; improve the dispatch of electricity; and call for the
shutting down of old, small, and less efficient coal-fired power plants in the province. It will also
result in an integrated regional grid that will facilitate the establishment of a regional competitive
power market, the Government’s major strategic reform agenda.

B.        Objectives and Scope

1. 

Objectives

46.
The  principal  objective  of  the  Project  is  to  increase  the  capacity  and  efficiency  of
electricity transmission from the northeastern part of the PRC to the southern part of Liaoning
Province,  thereby  increasing  the  availability  of  electricity  and  the  reliability  of  the  electricity
transmission  and  distribution  systems  in  Liaoning  Province  and  avoiding  harmful  emissions
associated  with  new  power  generation  in  the  densely  populated  southern  part  of  Liaoning
Province. Other objectives are to complete the upgrading and expansion of rural electrification
in the relatively poor rural areas of Liaoning Province, and to develop an integrated regional grid
that will enable restructuring of the power sector in Liaoning Province to introduce competitive
markets and use market forces to increase efficiency and productivity.

3. 

Project Area

a. 

Economy

48.
The GDP of Liaoning Province grew at 10.2 percent annually in real terms between 1990
and  1995,  and  at  8.6  percent  between  1996  and  2000.  The  GDP  growth  rate  in  1999  was  7.5
percent,43 whereas for 2000 it is estimated at 8.9 percent. Since 1995, the province has invested
more  than  $2  billion  equivalent  to  develop  its  infrastructure.  Priority  areas  for  further
development  are 
telecommunications,  and  urban
infrastructure,  energy, 
development.  The  economic  structure  of  the  province  is  dominated  by  heavy  industry  and
SOEs.  Heavy  industry  production  accounts  for  nearly  three  quarters  of  the  total  provincial

transportation 

                  

42 About  100,000  of  the  poorest  households  in  the  three  poverty  counties  and  one  poverty  city  will  receive  a  free
compact fluorescent of 13 watts with a lifetime of a minimum of five years. The total cost of the program is about Y2
million, which will be financed by LEPC, and produce annual energy savings of about Y1.2 million.

43 The  industry  sector  accounted  for  nearly  half  of  this  growth  rate,  while  the  services  and  agriculture  sectors
contributed  39.7  percent  and  10.9  percent,  respectively.  Investments  in  fixed  assets  accounted  for  about  21
percent of the growth rate.

 19

industrial output and 7 percent of the PRC’s total heavy industry production. Its industry sector
includes  iron  and  steel,  coal,  petrochemicals,  metallurgy,  machinery,  electronics,  shipbuilding,
building  materials,  papermaking,  and  textiles.  Mechanical  and  electrical  products  are  the
province's main export products. SOEs in Liaoning Province account for about one tenth of the
total  number  of  SOEs  in  the  PRC.  Major  cities  in  Liaoning  Province  are  Shenyang  with  a
population of 6.88 million, Dalian with a population of 5.54 million, and Fushun with a population
of 2.31 million.

b. 

Energy Resources

49.
In the northeast region, the main local resources of energy are coal, hydropower, and oil,
but production falls short of regional requirements. Coal deposits in the northeast region amount
to  71.3  billion  tons,  or  7  percent  of  the  PRC’s  total.  Coal  resources,  however,  are  unevenly
distributed and are mainly in Inner Mongolia (58 percent of total) and Heilongjiang (30 percent).
Liaoning  Province  accounts  for  only  9  percent  of  the  regional  total.  There  is  15.3  GW  of
exploitable hydropower resources in the northeast region with an average generation of 44 TWh.
Liaoning  Province  had  a  negative  net  energy  balance,  and  total  primary  commercial  energy
production  amounted  to  37.0  million  toe,  of  which  60  percent  consisted  of  coal,  36  percent  of
crude oil, and 4 percent of natural gas. In 1999, energy production declined by 12 percent from
its 1998 level, mainly due to a 17 percent decline in coal production, reflecting both a decline in
the  industrial  demand  for  coal  and  the  closure  of  small  and  uneconomic  coal  mines.  The  oil
production  of  the  northeast  region  is  largely  exported  to  other  parts  of  the  PRC.  In  1999,  the
primary commercial energy consumption of Liaoning Province was 58.0 million toe, its imports
of  primary  commercial  energy  were  21.1  million  toe,  and  its  deficit  between  production  and
consumption of primary commercial energy was about 36 percent.

c. 

Poverty Aspects

Liaoning  Province  has  a  population  of  about  41  million,  with  about  18.7  million  people
50.
living in urban areas and about 22.3 million in rural areas. Liaoning Province accounts for about
3  percent  of  the  PRC’s  entire  population  but  includes  about  10  percent  of  the  officially
unemployed  nationwide.  The  State  Council  Task  Force  for  Development  of  a  Social  Security
System  therefore  selected  Liaoning  Province  to  implement  a  social  security  reform  pilot
program,  which  is  to  test  new  approaches  to  social  security  reform  and  lead  to  nationwide
replication  of  those  that  prove  to  be  successful.  The  pilot  program  is  being  supported  by  the
ADB TA for Policy and Institutional Support for the Social Security Program (footnote 12). The
unemployed consist mainly of workers who were laid off due to closure and restructuring of the
large SOEs, which traditionally dominated the industry sector of Liaoning Province. In Shenyang
and  Dalian  the  unemployed  are  estimated  to  exceed  1.2  million,  of  whom  some  600,000  are
receiving a minimum subsistence payment of Y250 per month as determined by the provincial
government.  The  provincial  government  is  expecting  that  the  unemployment  rate  will  increase
further during the TFYP, because of additional layoffs and the entrance of about 300,000 new
job  seekers  into  the  labor  market  each  year.  During  this  period  the  provincial  government  is
planning  to  create  new  jobs,  for  about  three  million  people  through  (i)  export  of  labor  to  other
parts  of  the  PRC  or  abroad;  (ii)  establishing  small  and  medium-scale  enterprises,  township
enterprises, and private enterprises; and (iii) promoting the development of the services sector,
including retailing, tourism, and domestic services. The provincial and municipal governments in
Liaoning  Province  are  also  providing  direct  assistance  to  the  growing  number  of  urban
unemployed  by  (i)   introducing  preferential  access  policies  in  the  form  of  fee  exemptions  or
reductions for the urban poor in the areas of education, water, electricity, heating, and gas; (ii)
providing  preferential  policies  to  private  and  nonstate  enterprises  that  employ  laid-off  workers;

 20

(iii) developing physical infrastructure (especially roads and water supply) to promote economic
development  and  employ  laid-off  workers  for  construction;  (iv)  providing  microcredit,  tax
exemptions,  and  retraining  to  laid-off  workers  who  show  self-reliance  and  establish  private
businesses;  and  (v)  social  security  reform,  which  will  strengthen  the  management  and
administration of social security funds and their availability for eligible persons.

d. 

Load Forecast

The annual power demand in Liaoning Province grew by 4.5 percent per annum during
51.
1990–2000. As part of the least-cost generation planning for Liaoning Province, the Northeast
Power  Design  Institute  undertook  a  demand  forecast  for  electricity.  According  to  this  forecast,
consumption  would  increase  by  3.3  percent  in  2000,  4.2  percent  annually  from  2000  to  2005,
3.6 percent annually from 2006 to 2010, and 3.5 percent annually from 2011 to 2015. However,
the  growth  rate  in  electricity  consumption  in  2000  was  9.3  percent,  which  was  considerably
higher than the projected 3.3 percent. The main factor leading to this substantial increase was
the recovery in industrial production from a low level in the previous three years.

52.
Dalian is one of the major load centers in Liaoning Province, accounting for 15 percent
of the electricity demand of the province. Since Dalian will be the major beneficiary of the 500
kV  transmission  line  and  grid  rehabilitation,  a  separate  forecast  was  carried  out  on  future
electricity demand for the area covered by the Dalian Power Supply Bureau. GDP growth rates
for Dalian, which has been very successful in attracting foreign direct investment, have been the
highest in Liaoning Province (e.g., 11.8 percent growth in 2000). Dalian has a number of major
industries, including metallurgy, petroleum, chemicals, textiles, electronics, and food processing.
It  is  also  the  largest  ship  manufacturing  base  in  the  PRC  and  is  an  important  seaport.  Most
people are employed in about 970 enterprises in urban areas and about 150,000 township and
village enterprises. Together with its growth, Dalian has also maintained its position as a model
environment  city  in  the  PRC.  Electricity  consumption  in  Dalian  is  projected  to  grow  at  8.5
percent  in  2001,  7.9  percent  in  2002,  and  7.7  percent  in  2003.  In  the  long-term  forecast,  the
average growth rates are 7.7 percent for the period 2001–2005, 6.3 percent in 2006–2010, and
3.1  percent  in  2011–2015.  A  forecast  based  on  more  conservative  assumptions  about  the
growth  in  Dalian  resulted  in  average  consumption  growth  rates  of  6.8  percent  between  2001
and  2005,  5.7  percent  between  2006  and  2010,  and  4.0  percent  between  2011  and  2015.
Therefore, by doubling the power transmission capacity of the 500 kV interconnection with the
northern region and the consequent avoidance of emissions from new coal-fired power plants,
the Project will help maintain Dalian’s clean environment without suppressing the energy supply
needed for future economic growth.

e. 

Power Development Plan

The  least-cost  generation  expansion  analysis  covering  2000–2015  (planning  period)  for
53.
the  Liaoning  power  grid  (LPG)  was  carried  out  by  the  Economic  Research  Center  of  the  State
Power Corporation using the GESP II model.44 The input data and assumptions were reviewed by
the TA consultants and found appropriate. The least-cost analyses confirmed the robustness of
the Project. The Project will still be required, even if the demand growth slows to the average
consumption  growth  rates  of  3.6  percent  between  2000  and  2005,  3.2  percent  between  2005
and  2010,  and  2.5  percent  between  2010  and  2015  (low  growth  case  projected  by  the  TA
consultants). LPG is a subgrid of the grid that interconnects the northeast power region. A least-

than 10 power projects financed by the World Bank and ADB.

 21

cost  plan  was  also  undertaken  for  this  grid,  which  demonstrated  that  power  exports  from  the
northern part of the northeast power region to Dalian were justified.45

C.   

Technical Justification

1. 

Transmission Component

54.
The  construction  of  an  additional  500  kV  single  circuit  transmission  line  between
Shenyang    and    Dalian46    will    increase    the    power    transmission    capacity,    thereby    (i)
improving the reliability of the power supply in the highly industrialized Dalian area; (ii) enabling
increased  supply  of  power  to  rural  consumers;  (iii)  allowing  the  deferral  until  2010  of  new
generation capacity additions in the densely populated Dalian area, thereby avoiding increases
in  urban  pollution  resulting  from  additionally  required  coal-based  power  generation;  (iv)
eliminating  a  potential  transmission  bottleneck  in  power  trading  (and  so  unduly  high  bulk
electricity price in Dalian area) once the northeast power region adopts a competitive electricity
generating market structure; and (v) reducing transmission losses by about 23 MW to 122 MW
during the period 2002–2010.

55.
The Project is also a logical southward extension of the ADB-financed Northeast Power
Transmission Project, which involves the construction of a 500 kV single circuit transmission line
between  Harbin  in  Heilongjiang  Province  and  Shenyang  in  Liaoning  Province.  Once  all  the
sections are completed, this integrated 500 kV system will constitute the backbone transmission
system  with  a  total  length  of  more  than  2,000  km  (from  Yamin  in  the  Inner  Mongolia
Autonomous  Region  to  Dalian).  Since  this  backbone  will  have  the  economic  transmission
capacity  of  2,000  MW  and  the  short-term  transmission  capacity  of  nearly  5,000  MW,
transmission  bottlenecks  can  be  avoided  in  the  long  term  even  with  relatively  smaller
interconnections  from  new  load  centers  and  new  power  plants  to  the  backbone  transmission
system.  The  availability  of  the  strong  transmission  backbone  will  help  prepare  the  northeast
power region for developing into a competitive power market.

2. 

Distribution Component

Currently,  12.4  percent  of  the  population  in  the  project  area  are  poor  people  with  an
56.
average  annual  per  capita  income  of  Y1,000  in  rural  areas,  Y2,000  in  the  poverty  city,  and
Y3,000  in  the  urban  centers  of  the  municipalities  under  the  Project.  Poverty  counties/city  all
receive financial assistance from the central and provincial governments. As in other parts of the
PRC,  the  urban  and  rural  power  distribution  networks  in  Liaoning  Province  have  several
shortcomings:  (i)  since  originally  the  emphasis  was  on  connecting  industries,  the  network  for
connecting households is simple and weak, which has made rural power supply unreliable and
of poor quality; (ii) the rural network comprises two-wire, ground return, 10 kV subtransmission
systems that lead to technical losses of up to 50 percent in some counties and can be unsafe
during electrical fault conditions; and (iii) the rural tariff is nearly twice as high as that for urban
consumers.  The  Government  is  taking  steps  to  address  these  problems.  County  level  power

                  

45 There are large power exchanges between LPG and other subgrids. Liaoning Province is a net power importer. It
has received hydroelectricity from Jilin Province and thermal power from Heilongjiang and the eastern part of the
Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region each year, since the early 1980s.

46 At present, electricity is supplied to Dalian via a 500 kV, single circuit, transmission line and 220 kV transmission
lines. The 500 kV line has had five outages since it was commissioned in 1998, and it was out of service for a total
of  about  80  hours.  The  addition  of  the  proposed  transmission  line  will  improve  the  reliability  of  electricity  supply.
Further, it will be routed outside the eastern side of Shenyang, thus completing the 500 kV ring around the city that
will ensure more stable power supply to Shenyang.

 22

supply  companies  are  being  established  for  the  operation,  maintenance,  and  management  of
low voltage rural networks. In 1998, the Government allocated about Y180 billion (equivalent to
about  $22  billion)  to  these  power  supply  companies  to  rehabilitate  the  rural  power  grids.  The
three poverty counties and one poverty city under the Project have electricity supply constraints
that limit their use of electricity mainly to lighting. The rural electrification will benefit the rural poor
by  providing  incremental  electricity  needed  for  rural  development,  and  by  reducing  line  losses
and rural tariffs. About 30 percent of the rehabilitation work has been completed under the first
phase  (1998–2000),  while  the  balance  is  to  be  carried  out  during  the  second  phase  (2001–
2004).47  Since  the  rural  electricity  tariffs  are  relatively  high  and  the  distribution  of  electricity  in
rural areas is relatively inefficient, the rehabilitation of rural power distribution grids will produce
considerable financial and environmental benefits. In the cities of Shenyang and Dalian, LEPC
will  further upgrade  and  expand the urban distribution systems including the construction of
lines,  disconnecting  switches,  and
transformers,  surface  and  underground  distribution 
communication systems, which will increase the availability and reliability of electricity supply in
both cities.

4.

equivalent. The 2,000 affected employees will continue to be employed by LEPC. After closure
of the old power plants, they will help with the decommissioning and removal of the old power
plants and undergo training in operation of modern power plants for redeployment.

E.

Financing Plan

59.
An ADB loan of $100 million will finance the foreign exchange costs of the Project. The
remainder of the project cost will be financed by a contribution of $135 million equivalent from
internal cash generation by LEPC and a domestic loan of $240 million equivalent from the China
Construction Bank, which will have a repayment period of 13 years including a grace period of 3
years and an interest of 6.21 percent per annum.48

60.
The ADB loan is proposed to come from ADB’s ordinary capital resources. The loan will
carry a front-end fee of 1 percent, an interest rate to be determined in accordance with ADB’s
London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) based lending rate system for US dollar loans, and a
commitment  charge  of  0.75  percent  per  annum.  The  loan  will  have  a  repayment  period  of  24
years,  including  a  grace  period  of  4  years.  The  Borrower  will  be  the  Government  of  the  PRC,
which will make the loan available to LEPC through an onlending agreement on the same terms
and  conditions.  Disbursements  of  the  loan  proceeds  will  be  subject  to  SDPC’s  approval  of
LEPC’s  feasibility  study  for  the  Project.  LEPC  will  assume  the  foreign  exchange  and  interest
variation risks of the loan (Table 3).
