F.

Implementation Arrangements

1. 

Project Management

LEPC  will  be  the  EA  for  the  Project.  LEPC  has  established  a  project  implementation
61.
office  (PIO),  headed  by  a  project  director,  that  is  responsible  for  overall  project  coordination,
including procurement, accounting, and reporting functions, as well as for liaison with ADB. The
PIO comprises four sections and employs 18 persons, of whom 16 are on a full-time basis. The
PIO  will  establish  a  project  internet  site  to  provide  public  access  to  basic  information  about
project activities, including the status of the implementation schedule, the procurement process,
the  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  plan  (LARP),  and  the  environmental  monitoring  and
mitigation plan (EMMP).

2. 

Procurement

62.
All  goods  under  the  Project  to  be  wholly  or  partly  financed  by  ADB  will  be  procured  in
accordance with ADB's Guidelines for Procurement. The majority of the items financed by ADB
will  be  procured  on  the  basis  of  international  competitive  bidding  procedures  through  10
separate  tenders  using  ADB’s  standard  bidding  documents.  Other  items  that  are  expected  to
cost  less  than  $500,000  will  be  procured  on  the  basis  of  international  shopping  procedures.
LEPC will undertake all construction work under the Project and finance the same from its own
resources.    All  locally  financed  items  will  be  procured  by  LEPC  on  the  basis  of  procedures
acceptable to ADB. A list of all procurement packages, including those to be financed by ADB,
and  their  mode  of  procurement  is  in  Appendix  4.  In  view  of  LEPC’s  aim  to  begin  project
implementation by early 2002, ADB, at the request of the Government, has approved advance
procurement action with regard to goods financed under the Project.49

                  

49 Advance  procurement  action  covers  procurement  under  the  first  tender  documents  up  to  but  not  including  the
award of contract and was published in the electronic version of ADB Business Opportunities of 24 July 2001 and
in its printed version of September  2001 (volume 23, no. 9). The Government was informed that ADB approval of
advance action does not commit ADB to financing of this part (or any other part) of the Project.

 25

3. 

Consulting Services

63.
Under  the  Project,  project  implementation  consulting  services  will  be  required  to  assist
LEPC with (i) a review of the draft tender documents50 and evaluation of the bids received, (ii)
technical  advice  with  regard  to  the  design  of  the  project  facilities  as  required,  and  (iii)  project
management.  Also,  consulting  services  will  be  provided  for  power  market  development  in
Liaoning  Province  to  help  prepare  transmission  tariffs  for  the  Liaoning  power  grid  and  to
strengthen  the  operations  of  LEPC  in  preparation  for  its  new  role  as  a  power  transmission
company.  In  particular,  the  consultants  will  make  recommendations  for  improvements  in
capturing  business  costs  at  departmental/cost  center  levels,  financial  reporting,  budgeting,
management  administration,  staff  incentive  schemes,  and  auditing  systems  and  transparency.
All consultants will be financed by ADB and will be recruited by LEPC in accordance with ADB’s
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.  The  consulting  services  for  project  implementation  will
include  30  person-months  of  international  consulting  services,  and  those  for  power  market
development in Liaoning Province will include 31 person-months (comprising 15 person-months
of  international  consulting  services  and  16  person-months  of  domestic  consulting  services).  In
view  of  LEPC’s  aim  to  begin  project  implementation  by  early  2002  and  the  requirement  for
international consultants to assist LEPC with the evaluation of bids received in response to the
first tender documents and the review of subsequent tender documents, ADB, at the request of
the Government, has approved advance recruitment and retroactive financing for the consulting
services financed under the Project.51 Domestic consulting services for detailed engineering and
preparation  of  tender  documents  will  be  provided  by  the  Northeast  Power  Design  Institute,
which  is  an  experienced  organization  that  performed  satisfactorily  under  the  Northeast  Power
Transmission Project (footnote 41).

4. 

Implementation Schedule

64.
The  Project  will  be  implemented  over  a  period  of  about  three  and  a  half  years.
Preparatory  work  began  in  June  2001  with  the  drafting  of  the  first  bidding  documents  for
international  competition  bidding  (under  advance  procurement  action).  It  is  expected  that  the
transmission lines will become operational by late 2004 and that the Project will be completed
by the middle of 2005 with the commissioning of all facilities (Appendix 5).

Governance and Anticorruption

65.

government  officials.  Attention  was  drawn  to  the  section  on  fraud  and    corruption  that  was
added  to  ADB’s  Guidelines for Procurement,  particularly  the  need  for  bidders,  suppliers,  and
contractors  to  observe  the  highest  standards  of  ethics  in  the  procurement  and  execution  of
ADB-financed contracts, and the sanctions to be applied if fraud and corruption are discovered.
Similarly,  the  anticorruption  provisions  added  to  ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants
were discussed.

G.   

Executing Agency

1. 

Organization

68.
LEPC  was  officially  established  only  in  1999  following  the  reorganization  of  the  North
East  Power  Group.  LEPC  is  a  limited  liability  company  that  is  wholly  owned  by  SP.  It  is
responsible  for  undertaking  the  generation,  transmission,  and  distribution  functions  related  to
the heating and electric power industry in Liaoning Province. In 2000, the total installed capacity
in  Liaoning  Province  was  14,340  MW,  of  which  8,130  MW  was  owned  by  LEPC,  with  the
remainder  owned  by  SPC,  independent  power  producers,  and  local  government  agencies.
LEPC is implementing corporate restructuring by creating subsidiaries to manage specific parts
of its operations. The company has a network of wholly owned subsidiaries.

Day-to-day operations of the company are the responsibility of the General Manager. Its
69.
shareholding  includes  power  generating  plants,  power  distribution  companies,  construction
companies, and noncore businesses that are not related to the performance of the power utility
functions. When the power sector is restructured, LEPC should unbundle into successor power
generation companies, one electricity transmission company, and several electricity distribution
companies  for  the  urban  centers  and  counties.  LEPC  would  then  retain  the  responsibility  for
transmission  of  electricity  within  Liaoning  Province  and  fulfill  the  “single  buyer”  function  in  the
deregulated market. Under the current proposed framework for deregulation, LEPC will remain
the EA after further deregulation of the provincial power market.

2. 

Accounting and Financial Management

LEPC’s  finance  department  is  responsible  for  accounting  and  financial  management.
70.
The  finance  department  is  under  the  overall  supervision  of  the  chief  accountant  or  deputy
general  manager  for  finance  and  planning.  Separate  sections  are  responsible  for  tariffs,  cost
and  management  accounting,  capital  assets,  head  office  accounting,  and  internal  finance.
LEPC’s head office supervises the financial management functions of all its subsidiaries. LEPC
uses  accounting  systems  that  are  generally  in  accordance  with  internationally  accepted
accounting principles. Accounts are maintained at the level of the individual business units and
are consolidated for LEPC as a whole. The operating budget is prepared annually and reviewed
twice a year.

71.
The  financial  statements  of  LEPC  and  its  subsidiaries  are  audited  by  an  independent
external  auditing  firm.  The  financial  statements  are  submitted  to  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and
SPC  for  approval.  LEPC  has  its  own  internal  audit  division.  Under  the  Project,  LEPC  will
prepare annual financial statements consisting of income statements, sources and application of
funds, and balance sheets. It will also maintain project accounts adequate to identify goods and
services  financed  from  the  proceeds  of  the  ADB  loan.  LEPC  will  have  its  financial  statements
and  project  accounts  audited  in  accordance  with  generally  accepted  auditing  standards  by
external  auditors  acceptable  to  ADB,  and  will  submit  to  ADB,  not  later  than  nine  months  after
the  close  of  each  fiscal  year,  certified  copies  in  English  of  financial  statements,  audited
accounts,  and  the  auditor’s  report.  LEPC  will  implement  the  recommendations  for  further

Past Financial Performance  (1995–2000)

72.
The  past  financial  performance  of  LEPC  is  summarized  in  Table  4  and  detailed  in

5.   

Financial Viability of the Project

76.
LEPC  will  recover  its  cost  for  the  500  kV  component  of  the  Project  through  an
incremental transmission charge to be approved by the Pricing Bureau of Liaoning Province and
SDPC, and to be applied to all of LEPC’s electricity sales. Based on the present cost estimate it
is  envisaged  that  this  incremental  transmission  charge  will  be  Y0.0065  per  kWh.  It  will  cover
operating  costs  including  maintenance  and  depreciation  and  will  allow  a  reasonable  return  on
net fixed assets (of a minimum of 9 percent), adjusted for inflation, and cash generation to cover
debt  service  payments  and  working  capital  requirements.  The  further  design  of  transmission
tariffs  in  Liaoning  Province  will  be  supported  by  the  competitive  power  market  development
component under the Project.

 30

H. 

Environmental and Social Measures

1.   

 Environment

An  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  has  been  prepared  for  the  Project.  The  IEE
77.
does not anticipate significant environmental impacts, and, accordingly, the Project is classified
as environment category "B." The IEE confirms that the transmission line corridor will not cross
known  archeological  sites  or  pristine  natural  forest  and  has  been  routed  to  avoid  protected
areas.  The  transmission  line  will  traverse  150  km  of  land  classified  as  woodland,  which
comprises  secondary  natural  forest,  plantation  forest,  windbreaks,  and  orchards.  Along  such
segments, felling of trees required for stringing of transmission lines and construction of towers
will be compensated by tree planting in accordance with provincial regulations. The IEE reports
that the proposed route does not hinder wildlife migratory routes. As a precautionary measure,
however,  prior  to  commencement  of  the  construction  of  the  transmission  line  additional  study
will be undertaken to address possible impacts on migration of wild geese that may arise along
specific sections of the 80 km segment between Pulandian and Wafangdian counties where the
transmission  line  will  parallel  the  existing  500  kV  transmission  line.  Mitigation  measures  have
been  identified  to  address  relatively  minor  and  unavoidable  impacts  associated  with  the
construction  and  operation  phases.  Existing  standards  and  regulations  will  be  followed,
including those concerning exposure to electromagnetic radiation. An EMMP has been finalized
and reviewed by the Environment Protection Bureau of Liaoning Province and ADB, and will be
used during project implementation.

2.         Social Measures

78.
LEPC has submitted a LARP, which was found acceptable by ADB and was published
on ADB’s web site. A total of 95 households (401 persons) would need to be relocated under
the  Project.  The  construction  of  the  transmission  line  and  the  substations  will  require  the
permanent  acquisition  of  20.57  hectares  (ha),  of  which  9.97  ha  are  cultivated  farmland  and
10.60  ha  are  nonfarmland,  and  the  demolition  of  89  houses.  The  construction  of  the
transmission line and related facilities will also require the temporary use of 595.21 ha, of which
166.14  ha  are  farmland  and  429.07  ha  are  nonfarmland.  The  total  number  of  households
affected  by  the  Project  is  8,478,  comprising  25,567  persons.  All  will  receive  adequate
compensation,  rehabilitation,  and  income  restoration  in  accordance  with  the  provisions  of  the
LARP,  which  was  prepared  based  on  an  intense  public  consultations  involving  surveys  and
community  meetings  with  the  participation  of  implementing  agencies,  local  governments,  and
affected persons. An information booklet summarizing the LARP and compensation policy was
distributed to all affected persons, and a Chinese version of the LARP was made available to all
affected villages. The summary LARP is in Appendix 7.

 31

V.       PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A. 

Financial and Economic Analyses

1.

Financial Analysis

79.
LEPC  will  charge  all  its  customers  an  incremental  tariff  to  enable  it  to  undertake  the
Project. Although not all consumers will benefit directly from the new transmission line between
Shenyang  and  Dalian,  the  indirect  longer  term  benefit  as  a  result  of  the  establishment  of  a
competitive  market  for  power  generation,  facilitated  through  the  Project,  will  accrue  to  all
consumers.  Revenue  from  an  increase  of  Y0.0065/kWh  (at  2001  prices)  in  the  average  end-
consumer tariff for all electricity sold by LEPC yields a financial internal rate of return (FIRR) of
9.2  percent  in  comparison  with  LEPC’s  weighted  average  cost  of  capital,  estimated  at  2.8
percent (after tax and in real terms). Detailed calculations are shown in Appendix 8.

2.

Economic Analysis

a.

Least-Cost Analysis

Two least-cost generation expansion alternatives for the LPG were considered (covering
80.
2000-2015).  Alternative  I  is  the  base  case,  which  is  to  construct  the  500  kV  transmission  line
and grid rehabilitation to transmit electricity from the northeastern part of the northeast region to
Dalian.  Under  Alternative  II,  the  500  kV  transmission  line  and  grid  rehabilitation  would  not  be
constructed;  instead,  a  600  MW  thermal  power  plant  in  Dalian  is  considered  to  meet  the
demand  for  electricity.  The  results  indicate  that  the  least-cost  generation  expansion  scenario
including the Project compares favorably with the one without the Project.

The least-cost generation expansion analysis is supported by an equalizing discount rate
81.
(EDR)  analysis.  In  this  analysis,  costs  of  environmental  mitigation  measures  and  the
resettlement program have been included in the Project cost estimates. In the EDR analysis, the
500  kV  transmission  line  to  be  constructed  under  the  Project  will  replace  thermal  power
generation in Dalian. The analysis compares the investment and operation cost of the 500 kV
transmission line and  grid rehabilitation with that of a 600 MW thermal power plant. The main
assumptions  for  the  substitutes,  including  the  fuel  cost  and  capital  cost,  were  found  to  be
appropriate. The coal prices are taken from the latest World Bank commodity price projections.
Coal  consumption,  at  310  grams  of  coal  equivalent  per  kilowatt-hour  for  new  600  MW  units,
compares well with international values. The capital cost of a coal-fired power plant is $586 per
kilowatt,  based  on  the  capital  costs  of  some  recent  projects  in  the  PRC.  Transmission  and
distribution losses were estimated at 8 percent, and annual operation and maintenance costs of
transmission and distribution facilities at 2 percent of the capital investment cost. The results of
an  environmental  impact  evaluation  were  incorporated  into  the  EDR  analysis.  Without
environmental impact, the EDR shows that the 500 kV transmission line and grid rehabilitation is
superior  up  to  a  discount  rate  of  12.1  percent,  compared  with  the  alternative  of  locating  the
thermal plant in Dalian. If the national environmental benefits are taken into account, the EDR
increases  to  19.7  percent.  If  the  reliability  and  efficiency  improvement  of  the  transmission
system  are  taken  into  account,  the  levelized  unit  costs  show  that  the  unit  cost  of  producing
electricity in the northern part of the northeast power region and transmitting it to Dalian is only
about 0.3 percent lower than the cost of producing electricity in Dalian. However, if the adverse
environmental impacts of producing additional power at Dalian are taken into account, the cost
would be 7.5 percent lower than that of the alternative.

 32

b.

Economic Internal Rate of Return

82.
The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  calculations  cover  (i)  the  500  kV
transmission line and grid rehabilitation components, (ii) the rural electrification component, and
(iii) the whole Project. No separate analysis was undertaken for the competitive power market
development component due to the difficulties in quantifying its benefits. However, the costs of
this component have been included in the EIRR calculation for the whole Project.

83.
As in the least-cost analysis, the economic analysis used the conversion factors;
investment  costs  for  generation,  transmission,  and  distribution;  fuel  costs;  and  operation  and
maintenance costs where applicable. For EIRR calculations, the benefits of energy output were
valued  based  on  consumer  willingness  to  pay  and  on  end-consumer  tariffs.  Transmission  and
distribution losses were estimated based on the historical loss rates in the LPG. The results of the
EIRR  analysis  for  the  500  kV  transmission  line  and  grid  rehabilitation  components  show
efficiency  improvement  (reduced  losses)  and  increased  supply  as  the  major  benefits.  This
approach, which does not include the benefit of improved quality of supply, yielded an EIRR of
16.0  percent  for  the  transmission  component.  The  EIRR  analysis  for  the  rural  electrification
component  also  shows  efficiency  improvement  (reduced  losses)  and  increased  supply  as  the
major  benefits.  This  calculation,  which  does  not  include  the  impact  on  rural  economic
development  and  other  benefits,  yielded  an  EIRR  of  18.4  percent  for  the  rural  electrification
component.  The  EIRR  for  the  whole  Project    (without  national  environmental  benefits),  which
includes the costs for the competitive power market development component and the closure of
small, inefficient power plants component, is 18.5 percent.

84.
An economic evaluation of the environmental impacts of the Project, carried out based
on the benefits transfer method, used methodology adopted in ADB’s Workbook on Economic
Evaluation of Environmental Impacts (1996) to determine the adjusted estimate of the monetary
damages caused by air pollution during the study period, taking into account the location of the
power plant, emission levels, GDP growth, and the population affected.60 If the economic cost of
the environmental impacts of a comparable coal-fired power plant in Dalian were added to the
benefits  of  the  proposed  Project,  the  EIRR  for  the  for  the  500  kV  transmission  line  and  grid
rehabilitation  components  would  increase  to  17.9  percent,  and  for  the  whole  Project  to  24.9
percent. The environmental impacts of the rural electrification component, which are expected
to be positive and substantial, were not quantified due to difficulties in gathering the necessary
data (Appendix 9).

B. 

Environment

85.
The environmental benefits in the project area in terms of reduced emissions because of
the  closure  of  coal-fired  power  plants,  and  because  of  avoided  emissions  due  to  the
postponement  of  a  new  600  MW  coal-fired  power  plant  in  the  Dalian  area  and  efficiency
improvements in the rural electricity distribution system, are estimated at 324,600 tons of SO2,
164,600 tons of NOx, 215,100 tons of TSP, and 44.53 million tons of CO2. These benefits have
been  included  in  the  economic  evaluation  of  the  Project  (Appendix  10).  In  addition,  the
transportation  and  handling  of  about  1.3  million  tons  of  coal  a  year  from  the  Inner  Mongolia
Autonomous  Region  to  the  Dalian  area  will  be  avoided.  In  the  rural  areas  under  the  Project,

                  

60 The  estimates  of  average  annual  climate  change  for  carbon  emissions  were  also  carried  out  to  evaluate  the
monetary damages caused by greenhouse gas emissions. However, the estimated global environmental impacts
were not included in the economic analysis.

 33

households spend an average of 2–2.5 hours a day for cooking and require space heating for
about  four  months  a  year.  According  to  recent  medical  studies  the  average  incidence  rate  of
respiratory  diseases  (such  as  chronic  bronchitis,  throat  infection,  and  tonsillitis)  for  such  rural
households  is  about  78  percent,  which  is  about  50  percent  higher  than  for  areas  where
centralized  heating  is  provided.  The  health  benefits  associated  with  switching  from  the  use  of
fuelwood, straw, and coal to electricity are estimated to average Y156 per capita a year.61 LEPC
estimates  that  about  20  percent  of  the  rural  households  under  the  Project  will  completely
substitute fuelwood, straw, and coal for electricity within 5 years, and about 40 percent will do so
within  10  years.  The  average  health  benefits  for  the  rural  population  under  the  Project  are
estimated to be Y31 per capita a year by 2006 and Y62 per capita a year by 2011. At present
total straw and fuelwood consumption by the rural households under the Project is about 1.22
million tons a year, which would decrease by about 244,000 tons a year by 2006 and 488,000
tons a year by 2011. Also, the health benefits for women will be greater than for men. Based on
surveys,  it  was  found  that  women  do  about  96  percent  of  the  cooking  and  thus  inhale  more
smoke and emissions than do men.

C. 

Impact on Poverty 

86.
The transmission component of the Project will indirectly benefit the entire population of
12.2 million residing in the Project area, which includes the municipalities of Dalian, Shenyang,
Anshan, and Fushun, through efficiency improvement of electricity transmission and distribution.
This  area  includes  about  788,000  rural  poor  people  with  an  annual  per  capita  income  of  less
than Y1,000 and about 756,000 urban poor with an annual per capita income of not more than
Y3,000 for urban centers of the municipalities of Dalian, Shenyang, Anshan, and Fushun. The
rural  electrification  upgrading  and  transmission  component  of  the  Project  will  directly  benefit  a
total population of about 2 million in the three national poverty counties (Kanping, Xiuyan, and
Xianbin, which are the poorest among the nine national poverty counties in Liaoning Province)
and in Zhuanghe city,  which has been designated as a poverty city by Dalian municipality. Of
the 2 million, about 215,000 or about 10.8 percent are poor people (with an annual per capita
income  of  less  than  Y1,000  in  the  poverty  counties  and  Y2,000  in  the  poverty  city  under  the
Project). This component will make  electricity supply more reliable and affordable for the poor
(efficiency  gains  in  electricity  supply  of  15–20  percent  are  projected).  The  increased  use  of
electricity  by  the  poor  is  expected  to  decrease  the  use  of  alternative  fuels  such  as  straw,
firewood,  and  coal,  which  has  adverse  environmental  and  health  impacts.  The  incidence  of
poverty in the project area as a whole stands at 12.4 percent.

The  share  of  net  economic  benefits  directly  accruing  to  the  poor  is  estimated  at  17.3
87.
percent. Since this ratio is higher than the ratio of poverty population over total population in the
project  area  (12.4  percent),  the  Project  is  considered  to  support  pro-poor  growth.  The  17.3
percent share of net economic benefits does not include the indirect benefits of the Project that
would accrue to the poor, such as improved air quality and environment. The Project’s rural grid
rehabilitation  program  in  the  poverty  area  is  expected  to  generate  about  Y23.9  million  in
employment benefits for unskilled labor. In addition, local procurement of the materials required
for  the  program  is  expected  to  create  about  1,600  new  jobs,  which  will  require  about  Y17.1
million in paid wages to provide the materials. Under the proposed tariff reforms, rural electricity
tariffs  for  residential,  industrial,  commercial,  agricultural,  and  other  consumers  will  decline  by
13.7 percent, 37.7 percent, 2.9 percent, 34.6 percent, and 33.4 percent, respectively by 2004.
This  will  produce two direct benefits for the rural consumers: it will (i) increase rural electricity

                  

61 Including avoided medical cost and absence from work. The estimate is comparable to the estimate made by Xia

Gang in 1997 in An Estimate of the Economic Consequences of Environmental Pollution in China.

 34

consumption, and (ii) provide cost savings as a result of lower electricity tariffs. The successful
implementation  of  the  rural  tariff  reduction  program  has  the  potential  to  set  a  precedent  that
could  be  widely  replicated  in  the  PRC.  This  would  have  far-reaching,  positive  impacts  on  the
poor, since poverty in the PRC is largely a rural phenomenon.

D. 

Risks

88.
A  careful  load  forecast  with  regard  to  the  projected  increase  in  power  demand  in  the
Dalian area has been carried out, where shortage in power supply is projected. With the Project,
LEPC will have no major problems in transmitting surplus power from the north in the northeast
power  region.  The  Project  remains  financially  and  economically  viable  if  there  is  a  more
moderate economic growth in the Dalian area. Thus a lower load growth is not a major project
risk.  As  the  Project  is  based  on  proven  design  and  the  proposed  technology  has  been
successfully  used  in  the  PRC,  no  significant  technical  risks  are  anticipated.  The  risk  of  a
significant construction delay is low, given LEPC’s proven experience in the implementation of
large-scale transmission projects in the PRC and abroad, and the assistance to be provided by
project implementation consultants. Financial sustainability of the Project and LEPC is assured
through the implementation of agreed upon tariffs during project implementation, and close ADB
monitoring of the same.

To  complement  the  deterministic  economic  analysis,  a  probabilistic  risk  analysis  was
89.
performed using the Monte Carlo simulation technique62 (Appendix 11). Six parameters, namely
capital cost, foreign exchange rate, implementation delay, willingness to pay, incremental power
supply, and line loss reduction benefits, were selected as the crucial risk variables because of
their  significant  impact  on  the  Project’s  economic  viability.  The  probability  of  the  EIRR  falling
below 12 percent is about 11 percent. The expected EIRR, based on the weighted average of
all simulated combinations is 15.8 percent (with a standard deviation of 2.9 percent63), about 2.7
percentage points lower than the base case value without consideration of project risks.

90.
In addition to the risk analysis, a sensitivity analysis was carried out to test the impact of
variations  in  some  parameters  on  the  EIRR  and  FIRR.  The  results  indicate  that,  even  under
adverse conditions, the EIRR would be 13.7 percent and the FIRR would be in the order of 6.9
percent,  which  is  above  LEPC’s  estimated  weighted  average  cost  of  capital  of  2.8  percent  in
real terms after tax. Changes in the foreign exchange rate of the Yuan within reasonable limits
would  not  constitute  a  risk  to  the  viability  of  the  Project.  The  tariff-setting  mechanism  allows
LEPC to recover all costs including operating costs and debt-service requirements and to earn a
reasonable rate of return on net fixed assets (Table 6).

                  

62 The  simulation  was  carried  out  using  the  Risk  Master  computer  software.  Monte  Carlo  simulation  works  by
generating  a  series  of  random  numbers  following  the  distribution  of  probability  of  each  risk  variable.  For  each
simulation, which represents a combination of different states of risk variables, EIRRs are calculated and recorded.
The results of 3,000 simulations are then averaged.

63 A  common  statistical  indicator  of  the  risk  of  a  project  is  the  standard  deviation,  which  measures  the  dispersion
around the expected value. The greater the variability, the less confident can one be of the outcomes associated
with the project. A standard deviation of 3.1 indicates that, in general, the Project is a low-risk one.

 ELECTRICITY TARIFFS AND TARIFF REFORMS IN THE LIAONING POWER GRID

40

Appendix 2, page 1

A. 

Introduction

1.
Achieving the right balance between the benefits of market pricing for electricity and other
social goals is one of the critical issues faced by developing countries. In the past, the Government
of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) used subsidies extensively while aiming to achieve fair
and cost-reflective electricity pricing. Electricity pricing affects demand in the medium and longer
term,  and  contributes  to  rational  electricity  use,  increased  economic  efficiency,  and  greater
prosperity. Marginal and opportunity cost pricing provides a principle for appropriate electricity tariff
levels  and  structures.  Social,  economic,  and  fiscal  measures  (based  on  the  taxation  and
distribution policies of governments) are important in mitigating against the impact of marginal cost
pricing  on  the  most  vulnerable  segments  of  the  population.  It  is  a  priority  for  the  Government  to
cooperate  with  electricity  providers  and  establish  a  fair  and  cost-reflective  tariff  system  for
electricity services and reduce or eliminate nontechnical losses.

B. 

2. 

(i)

(ii)

Current Tariff Structure and Levels

The  current  uniform  tariffs  at  the  provincial  level  of  the  Liaoning  Power  Grid  (LPG)
comprise

catalog tariffs1 applied to recover (a) costs of state grants for all plants built before 1985;
(b)  loans  from  the  Government  for  many  of  the  plants  built  after  1985;  and  (c)  costs  of
power  plants  financed  by  joint  investment  from  State,  provincial  and  local  governments,
plants  of  independent  power  producers,  and  plants  owned  by  local  governments  or
industries that sell surplus power to the grid; and

state  and  local  surcharges  added  to  consumer  tariffs  across  the  province.2  These
surcharges  are  estimated  to  be  6.3  percent  of  electricity  bills  paid  by  end  consumers  in
2001.

3.
The  end-consumer  tariff  structure  of  the  Liaoning  Electric  Power  Company  Ltd  (LEPC)
comprises  six  consumer  categories:  residential,  nonresidential  lighting,  commercial,  non-industry
and general industry,3 large industry, and agriculture. A one-time connection fee is applied to new
consumers  connected  to  the  network,  which  is  determined  on  the  basis  of  the  need  to  cover
investments  at  the  subtransmission/distribution  level.  In  addition,  a  two-part  tariff,  consisting  of
capacity and energy charges, is applied only to large industrial consumers. The capacity charge is set
at Y22/kilowatt (kW)/month at maximum demand (and Y15/kW/month for transformer capacity), which
is low considering the capacity cost in the LPG. There is no capacity charge for all other consumers.
Between  1990  and  2000,  the  real  end-consumer  tariffs  increased  on  average  by  7.7  percent
annually.

Based on the estimated long run marginal cost (LRMC)4 of electricity supply and the load
4.
characteristics  in  Liaoning  Province,  the  economic  tariffs  by  consumer  categories  and  voltage
levels  were  estimated  a  comparison  was  made  between  the  current  end-consumer  tariffs  and
LRMC tariffs. It must be noted that end-consumer tariffs include various government levies that do
not  accrue  to  the  utility.  Hence,  these  tariffs,  as  a  percentage  of  LRMC,  overstate  what  actually
accrues  to  LEPC.  While  industry  and  the  category  of  other  consumers  are  paying  tariffs  higher

than  the  estimated  economic  costs,  residential,  commercial,  and  agricultural  users  are  paying
tariffs below their economic costs. Residential consumers are the main recipients of subsidies. The

of  the  average  LRMC  of  supply  at  Y0.44/kWh  ($0.053/kWh).5  If  levies  not  accruing  to  LEPC  are
deducted, it decreases to 89 percent of LRMC.

With  the  adjustment  of  industrial  structure  and  the  rapid  increase  in  people’s  living
5.
standards, the gap between peak and off-peak demand in Liaoning Province has been expanding.
The difference of supply costs between peak and off-peak demand is also increasing. At present,
time-of-day (TOD) tariffs are applied to some consumer categories of the LPG.6 In 2000, the ratio
of peak to flat energy charge was 150 percent, while the ratio of valley to flat energy charge was
50  percent.  However,  corresponding  LRMC  ratios  would  be  about  300  percent  and  70  percent,
respectively.  The  tariff  blocks  are  quite  large:  11  hours  for  the  peak  block,  6  hours  for  the  flat
block,  and  7  hours  for  the  valley  block.  The  consumers  do  not  have  much  flexibility  to  shift  their
consumption  away  from  the  peak  hours.  Therefore,  the  current  TOD  tariffs  do  not  provide  a
sufficient incentive for customers to shift their electricity consumption away from peak hours.

6.
The present tariff structure in the LPG is relatively complex and inequitable, does not fully
reflect  the  structure  of  supply  costs,  and  does  not  provide  adequate  incentives  for  electricity
conservation. Within the same consumer category, consumption at lower voltage level is charged
at higher tariff, but the difference is small compared with the difference in supply costs. The current
pricing  system,  which  involves  substantial  economic  subsidies  for  residential  consumers,  is  not
conducive to the efficient use of electricity. Among the consumer categories, the tariff for industrial
consumers (Y0.425 /kWh) is higher than the LRMC of supply estimated at Y0.394/kWh. The tariffs
for  residential  consumers  (Y0.323/kWh)  were  only  55.6  percent  of  the  LRMC  of  supply
(Y0.581/kWh),  and  the  tariffs  for  agricultural  consumers  (Y0.308/kWh)  were  65.4  percent  of  the
LRMC  of  supply  (Y0.471/kWh).  As  in  other  provinces  in  the  PRC,  residential  consumers  are  the
main  recipients  of  the  economic  subsidies.  The  pattern  of  cross-subsidies  suggests  that  the
industry sector largely subsidizes electricity consumption in the agriculture and residential sectors.

Tariff  reforms  in  the  PRC  need  to  take  into  account  ongoing  power  sector  reforms.
7.
Historically,  the  electricity  supply  in  the  PRC  has  been  considered  a  natural  monopoly,  with
economies of scale providing the least-cost supply options, and vertically integrated utilities were
established under average cost pricing regulation. However, there is a general trend now for the
power  industry  to  be  restructured  from  a  regulated  monopoly  to  a  competitive  market-based
structure.  At  present,  the  Government  is  undertaking  a  wide-ranging  institutional  restructuring
program in the power sector. As LEPC’s power generation functions are progressively unbundled
as  independent  power  producers,  the  tariff  level  and  structure  need  to  be  adjusted  to  meet  the
purchase, transmission, and distribution costs of electricity, and to provide a reasonable return on
investment in transmission and distribution facilities. The development of appropriate transmission
and  distributional  tariffs  will  be  supported  under  the  competitive  power  market  development
component of the Project.

                  

5(cid:1) The  concept  of  marginal  cost  pricing  is  useful  in  attempting  to  optimize  the  allocation  of  resources.  However,  the
higher  tariffs  that  may  result  from  the  application  of  this  principle  could  be  detrimental  to  a  country's  industrial
competitiveness  or  might  deprive  lower  income  consumers  of  an  essential  service.  In  any  case,  marginal  cost
valuation provides valuable guidance in establishing the tariff structure even if the level of marginal costs is not totally
recovered in the average tariff.

6  The division of the TOD system is as follows: (i) peak period: 9:00-11:00, 14:00-21:00, (11 hours); (ii) flat period: 7:00-
8:00,  12:00-13:00,  22:00-23:00  (6  hours;  (iii)  valley  period:  24:00-6:00  (7  hours).  The  present  peak  consumption  is
affected by a 50 percent surcharge above the base catalog tariffs. Consumption during the valley period receives a 50
percent discount.

C. 

Progress of Tariff Reforms in Liaoning Province

LEPC has undertaken tariff reforms7 in the following areas: (i) unifying consumer tariffs for
8.
each  consumer  category  under  each  of  the  provincial  level  power  systems;  (ii)  rationalizing  the
classification  of  consumer  categories  and  making  adequate  increases  in  the  tariff  differential  for
power  supplies  at  adjacent  voltage  levels  to  reflect  supply  costs;  and  (iii)  improving  the  two-part
tariff system, consisting of capacity and energy charges, by increasing the capacity charge.

9.
Uniform  consumer  tariffs  for  each  consumer  category  at  the  provincial  level  became
effective  in  July  2000.  Substantial  progress  was  made  in  improving  tariff  level  and  structure  in
Liaoning  Province.  Most  of  the  local  surcharges  were  eliminated  by  the  end  of  1998,  and  the
classification of consumer categories was rationalized to include a commercial category in 2000.8
There were also improvements in the two-part tariff system by increasing the capacity charge for
large industrial consumers from Y18/kW/Month in 1997 to Y22/kW/month in 2000, which represents
an increase of 22 percent. There was also some increase in the tariff differential for power supplies
at adjacent voltage levels to reflect supply cost. The average end-consumer tariff in the LPG was
increased from Y0.396/kWh in 1997 to Y0.418/kWh in 2000. In 1997, TOD tariffs applied only to
large  industrial  consumers,  and  the  share  of  energy  sales  applied  to  TOD  tariff  was  only  30
percent  of  LEPC’s  total  energy  sales.  In  2000,  large  industrial,  non-industrial,  and  commercial
users could avail of TOD tariffs, and the share of TOD energy sales increased to 65.6 percent of
total LEPC energy sales.

D. 

Further Tariff Reforms in Liaoning Province

10.
Following  a  tariff  study  carried  out  by  domestic  consultants  and  in  consultation  with  the
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  LEPC  has  prepared  a  Tariff  Reform  Action  Plan.  The  plan
includes  a  detailed  implementation  schedule  and  an  assessment  of  the  impact  of  the  proposed
tariff  adjustments  on  residential  consumers.  The  proposed  new  tariff  system  is  based  on  LRMC
principles  and  is  compatible  with  ongoing  power  market  reforms.  The  relevant  provincial  and
Central government authorities support the implementation of the plan.

11.
Currently, the average tariffs, including government levies not accruing to LEPC,  are about
95  percent  of  the  LRMC  of  supply,  which  is  considered  a  reasonable  level.  The  proposed  tariff
reforms  envisaged  under  the  plan  will  focus  on  making  further  adjustments  to  the  pricing  of
electricity based on the economic cost of supply and will improve the tariff structure to better reflect
economic costs. The following milestones have been agreed upon:

E. 

Tariff Reforms in Rural Areas in Liaoning Province

To  reduce  the  use  of  coal  and  biomass  for  energy  generation  and  to  promote  economic
16.
development in rural areas, the Government is aiming to provide a basic supply of grid-connected
electricity  to  all  rural  consumers  at  an  affordable  tariff.  For  this  purpose,  a  rural  electrification
campaign was begun in 1998 whereby the fixed costs of rural electrification are largely borne by
the  Government  through  dedicated  funding  and  the  connection  costs  are  partially  or  totally
absorbed by the service provider. In addition to the rural electrification program, the Government
also instructed the provincial electricity companies to reduce rural tariffs and bring them in line with
the  tariff  levels  for  urban  consumers.  There  would  be  an  implicit  subsidy  when  rural  consumers
have  the  same  electricity  tariff  as  urban  consumers,  because  the  cost  of  supplying  electricity  to
rural  areas  is  higher  than  to  urban  areas.  However,  the  Government  considers  that  such
temporary subsidies are justified, as its objective is to ensure that the rural population, in particular
the poor, have access to affordable electricity.

Action Plan for Rural Tariff Reforms

1.

(i)

By  December  2002,  electricity  supply  companies  at  the  county  level  will  complete
the  installation  of  meters  for  all  households  and  implement  uniform  tariffs  for  all
consumers in each county.

 44

Appendix 2, page 5

(ii)

(iii)

(iv)

By  December  2003,  the  same  tariff  will  be  applied  to  rural  consumers  under  the
same category. The tariffs for different categories will be reduced to incorporate the
efficiency gains as a result of improved rural electrification.

By December 2004, all rural consumers in Liaoning Province will be subject to the
same  tariffs  in  line  with  the  corresponding  tariffs  by  category  and  by  voltage  level
applied  to  urban  consumers  in  the  province.  This  will  effectively  meet  the
Government’s objective to bring the rural tariffs more in line with urban tariffs.

Consistent  with  ADB’s Guidelines on Subsidies,  between  2005  and  2010,  all  rural
tariffs  will  be  gradually  adjusted  toward  the  LRMC  tariffs  in  rural  areas.  The
Government will abolish all subsidies on electricity supply to rural areas by 2010.

2.

Study on Lifeline Tariff

17.
A  lifeline  tariff  study  will  be  conducted  by  LEPC  with  a  view  to  introduce  lifeline  tariffs  in
Liaoning Province. The determination of the desirable level of a lifeline tariff will take into account
the  electricity  consumption  patterns  and  the  percentage  of  disposable  income  that  rural
households use for purchase of electricity, in terms of purchasing power parity. Lack of electricity
supply  to  meet  basic  needs  could  create  negative  impacts  on  health,  education,  and  economic
development. It is envisaged that temporary "lifeline tariffs” that are justified, explicit, targeted and
transparent will be established for rural and urban residential consumers as a result of the study.

Financial  Impact  of  Tariff  Reforms  for  LEPC  and  Affordability  of  Tariff  Reforms  for

F.
Consumers

18.
The impact of the proposed tariff reforms on LEPC’s financial performance was assessed
as  well  as  the  affordability  of  tariff  reforms  for  the  concerned  households.  Since  the  tariffs  for
industrial  and  commercial  consumers  will  decrease  under  the  proposed  tariff  reforms,  the
affordability assessment has been limited to rural and urban residential consumers.

1.

Financial Impact of the Proposed Tariff Reforms on LEPC

19.
The financial impact of tariff adjustments on LEPC’s financial performance was assessed
by  examining  LEPC’s  financial  performance  with  and  without  the  proposed  tariff  reforms.  The
results  indicate  that,  even  with  the  proposed  decrease  in  rural  tariffs  from  Y0.673/kWh  to
Y0.592/kWh  in  2005,  LEPC’s  financial  performance  will  improve.  This  is  mainly  the  result  of
efficiency  gains  in  the  transmission  and  distribution  of  electricity  brought  about  by  the  improved
rural electrification system and the new tariff structure under the tariff reform action plan.

2. 

Affordability of Tariff Reforms for Residential Consumers

20.
The  affordability  of  reforms  was  assessed  for  residential  consumers  in  rural  and  urban
areas. Traditionally, electricity subsidies between customer categories, i.e., cross-subsidies, have
been used in the PRC, without taking into consideration the consumers’ ability to pay or their level
of  consumption.  By  2005,  urban  residential  consumers  are  expected  to  spend  about  1  percent
more  of  their  disposable  income  on  electricity  (from  2.75  percent  to  3.80  percent)  whereas  rural
residential  consumers  are  expected  to  spend  about  0.5  percent  less  (from  2.46  percent  to  2.01
percent). These percentages are considered to be at an affordable level and comparable with such
percentages in other developing countries.

 45

Appendix 2, page 6

G. 

Poverty Impact of Proposed Tariff Reforms

The proposed tariff reforms involve well-targeted and temporary subsidies to reflect social
21.
concerns.  The  proposed  lower  rural  tariffs  could  benefit  those  who  really  need  them  and  will
enhance the accessibility, availability, and acceptability of electricity services in the rural areas of
Liaoning Province. The subsidies involved are visible in terms of their size, transparent in terms of
their  sources  and  beneficiaries,  and  subject  to  reduction  within  a  prescribed  time  period.  The
proposed tariff reforms envisage the elimination of all subsidies for rural electricity supply by 2010.

The proposed tariff reforms will be beneficial for the poor in the rural areas of province.10
22.
Under  the  proposed  tariff  reforms,  rural  electricity  tariffs  for  residential,  industrial,  commercial,
agricultural,  and  other  consumers  will  decline  by  13.7  percent,  37.7  percent,  2.9  percent,  34.6
percent, and 33.4 percent, respectively, by 2004.  This will produce two direct benefits for the rural
consumers: it will (i) increase rural electricity consumption, and (ii) provide cost savings as a result
of lower electricity tariffs. The increase in electricity consumption in the rural areas of province is
expected to lead to an average increase of the annual per capita income of Y23. Using an average
annual  per  capita  income  of  Y1,000  for  the  poor  in  the  rural  areas.11  the  increase  in  electricity
consumption could lead to a 2.3 percent annual increase in the per capita income for the rural poor
in Liaoning Province.12 Based on LEPC’s projections for rural electricity consumption in the coming
years, the cost savings for households as a result of the proposed tariff reforms would be about
Y16.8  billion  between  2003  and  2007.  If  it  is  further  assumed  that  such  savings  will  be  used  for
investments in productive activities, this could lead to an increase in the average annual per capita
income  of  Y77  in  the  rural  areas  of  the  province  over  a  period  of  five  years.  In  comparison  with
their  average  annual  per  capita  income  of  Y1,000,  this  would  imply  an  average  increase  in  per
capita income of 7.7 percent between 2003 and 2007. Together the two direct effects could thus
lead  to  an  increase  of  about  19.2  percent  in  the  average  per  capita  income  of  the  rural  poor  in
Liaoning Province between 2003 and 2007.

A.

Financial Projections

The financial operations of the Liaoning Electric Power Company (LEPC) were projected
1.
for  the  period  2001-2010  as  shown  in  Tables  1-3  based  on  the  major  assumptions  described
below.

B. 

General

1.

Capital investment Program

The capital investment program of LEPC is based on the least-cost power development

2.
plan for Liaoning Province.

2.

Demand Forecast

3.
The  electricity  sales  projections  are  based  on  the  load  growth  forecast  prepared  by
LEPC with the assistance of its consultants, the SP Power Economic Research Center and the
consultants for the preparation of the project feasibility study. Electricity sales are projected to
increase  by  4.5  percent  in  2001,  4.0  percent  thereafter  annually  up  to  2004,  and  3.5  –  3.8
percent annually up to 2010. Although the projected electricity sales growth of 20-22 percent for
the periods 2001-2005 and 2005-2010 is slightly higher than the sales growth for 1995-2000 (17
percent),  it  is  considered  reasonable,  taking  into  account  the  gross  domestic  product  growth
projections for the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and the lower rates during 1997-1999 due
to the Asian financial crisis and overall state-owned enterprise reform.

3.

Prices, Inflation, and Exchange Rate

4.
Foreign costs are estimated to increase at about 2.4 percent a year over the projection
period. The annual escalation rates of local currency costs are assumed at 2.5 percent for 2002,
and 4 percent thereafter. The projections use an exchange rate of Y8.30 to $1.00.

C.

Income Statements

1.

Revenue

5.
Revenue is calculated from the electricity sales and the average tariff (unit revenue) per
kilowatt  hours  (kWh)  of  electricity  sold.  Annual  tariff  increases  are  based  on  the  average
between  an  annual  tariff  increase  of  0.38  percent  (in  real  terms),  which  will  provide  LEPC  a
return on net fixed assets of 5 percent, and of 1.3 percent (in real terms) as projected by LEPC.
A one-time adjustment of Y0.0065/kWh (real 2001 prices) is assumed for the 2005 incremental
tariff  as  the  cost  recovery  mechanism  for  the  Project.  This  adjustment  reflects  an  extra  1.45
percent  price  increase  for  all  LEPC  customers  to  provide  approximately  Y450  million  as  the
revenue of LEPC for each subsequent year.

2.

Cost of Coal

6.
LEPC’s average consumption of standard coal (7,000 kilocalories per kilogram) is about
430 grams/kWh; this will decline by about 2 grams/kWh annually due to the installation of new
thermal  power  plants.  The  cost  of  standard  coal  in  Liaoning  Province  was  Y305/ton  in  2000.
This  price  is  expected  to  increase  by  4  percent  between  2001  and  2004  and  by  6  percent
thereafter. The coal price appears higher than the current international price of coal ($30/ton or

Y260/ton),  where  the  PRC  is  a  significant  player  in  the  market.  It  is  considered  a  reasonable

power  stations  and  sale  of  power  stations,  LEPC’s  dependency  on  coal  will  be  significantly
diminished over the next-five year period (from 1,020,000 tons in 2000 to 102,000 tons in 2005).

3.

Purchase of Power

7.
LEPC  purchases  power  from  other  power  producers  to  meet  increasing  customer
demands  above  its  own  installed  capacity.  Power  purchased  from  small  independent  power
plants in the next five years will have a purchase price between Y0.15/kWh and Y0.26/kWh in
constant 2000 prices. These prices may be considered on the lower end of the spectrum in light
of the current new entry price for new generation. However, this assumption, does not pose a
risk for LEPC, as under the proposed deregulation in the PRC, LEPC is most likely to become
the regulated transmission company with a guaranteed reasonable return by the regulator, while
the generation and distribution functions will transferred to other entities.

4.

Other Operating Expenses

Other  operating  costs 

8.
include  personnel,  distribution,  administration,  and  other
expenses.    These  are  projected  to  increase  in  accordance  with  the  increase  in  electricity
generation and distribution operations. The wage escalation rate is assumed to be 4 percent for
every year.  In 2000, the total sales were 54,863 gigawatt hour (GWh); since LEPC employed
63,000 people, this was 0.87 GWh sold per employee. This figure is significantly low relative to
similar  vertically  integrated  electricity  utilities  in  other  countries.  A  figure  of  1.2  GWh  per
employee  or  higher  is  not  uncommon  even  in  some  Asian  countries.  So  in  the  event  of
deregulation in the PRC’s electricity industry, the operational expenses are likely to be less than
the forecast levels used in this document.

5.

Depreciation

9.
Depreciation is calculated on a straight-line basis that uses the estimated remaining life
of  the  fixed  assets.  A  straight-line  depreciation  of  4.36  percent  is  assumed  over  22  years  of
project life.

Investments  of  LEPC  are  estimated  to  earn  interest  at  the  short-term  interest  rate  of  6

SUMMARY LAND ACQUISITION AND RESETTLEMENT PLAN

A. 

Introduction

The implementation of land acquisition and resettlement activities for the Project
1.
will be governed by the Land Acquisition and Resettlement Plan (LARP). The LARP was
prepared by the Liaoning Electric Power Company Ltd (LEPC) in full compliance with the
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)'s  Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy  as  detailed  in  the
ADB Handbook on Resettlement: A Guide to Good Practice.

B. 

Resettlement Policy of the LARP

The resettlement policy in the LARP reflects both the Borrower’s regulations and
2.
ADB’s  Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy.  The  main  principles  of  the  policy  are  that  (i)
negative impacts will be minimized as much as possible, (ii) resettlement/compensation
will be carried out so as to improve or at least restore the preproject living standards of
the  affected  people  (AP),  (iii)  the  AP  will  be  thoroughly  informed  and  consulted  on
compensation  options  and  the  design  of  resettlement  plans,  (iv)  compensation  of
affected  assets  will  be  provided  at  replacement  cost,  and  (v)  compensation  for  lost
assets and subsidies will be provided in full prior to ground leveling and demolition.

3. 
The  resettlement  policy  in  the  LARP  stipulates  eligibility  and  entitlement
provisions  for  the  Project’s  AP.  These  entail  provisions  for  land,  house,  and  crops
losses, and for resettlement subsidies, as follows:

Permanent land losses  will  be  compensated  as  follows: (a) AP  affected
by  agricultural  and  residential  land  losses  will  be  compensated  through
“land  x  land”  arrangements  by  means  of  land  reallocation  within  village
domains;  (b)  cash  compensation  for  lost  land  will  be  paid  at  rates
stipulated  by  the  1998  Land  Law  to  the  villages,  which,  in  turn,  will  use
the  funds  received  for  infrastructure  and  services  directly  benefiting  the
affected communities; and (c) the rate selected for land compensation is
equivalent to 10 times the average annual output value (AAOV) over the
three years prior to land acquisition.

(ii) 

Temporary land losses  will  be  compensated  directly  to  the  AP  at  a  rate
corresponding to two times the AAOV.

(iii)  House  losses  will  be  directly  compensated  to  the  AP  in  cash  at

replacement cost free of demolition expenses and salvaged materials.

(i) 

(iv)

include 

Crops  losses  will  be  directly  compensated  to  the  AP  in  cash  at  the  rate
equivalent  to  the  AAOV  for  each  harvest  lost.  The  AP  will  also  receive
(a)  a  land  relocation  subsidy
various  subsidies.  These 
corresponding  to  15  times  the  AAOV,  to  be  paid  directly  to  the  AP
affected by permanent land losses; (b) a resettlement subsidy equivalent
to  Y1,050,  to  be  paid  directly  to  each  resettled  household  for  transport
costs,  work  loss,  transfer  costs,  medical  expenses,  and  temporary
housing;  and  (c)  a business losses allowance  equivalent  to  a  monthly
quota of Y2,000, to be paid to each AP losing business income for each
month of interruption of business activities.

 56

Appendix 7, page 2

C.

Resettlement and Land Acquisition Impacts

4. 
Project construction will require the permanent acquisition of 9.97 hectares (ha)
of farmland and 10.60 ha of nonfarmland and will temporarily occupy 595.21 ha  (166.14
ha of farmland and 429.07 ha of nonfarmland). Project implementation will also require
the  demolition  of  89  houses    (in  all  5,560  square  meters  [m2])  and  a  small  apartment
building (1,000 m2). Other losses are 61 animal pens; 23 wells; 2,980 m2 of barns; 4,750
m2 of fences; and 95 toilets.

5. 
AP who need to be relocated comprise 401 persons (95 households.)  A total of
3,020 AP (1,004 households) will be affected by permanent land acquisition caused by
the construction of tower foundations, while 179 AP (53 households) will be affected by
permanent  land  acquisition  connected  to  substation  construction  or  expansion.  Some
21,967 AP (7,326 households) will be affected by temporary land acquisition.

D.

Rehabilitation/Income Restoration Measures

6. 
Land  compensation  provided  to  the  villages  will  be  used  to  finance  various
rehabilitation  and  income  restoration  programs.  These  include  the  implementation  of
local
agricultural  extension  programs, 
enterprises, and training activities.

the  expansion  or  establishment  of  new 

7.
In addition, special provisions will be delivered to vulnerable households and to
severely affected AP. Vulnerable households (households with per capita income below
$1/day, households headed by widows or divorced women, or households composed by
elderly  AP)  will  be  entitled  to  a  subsidy  of  Y6,000  under  a  special  Social  Assistance
Fund directly financed by LEPC. Severely affected households (AP losing more than 10
percent  of  their  land,  or  AP  who  need  to  be  relocated)  will  each  receive  two  training
subsidies of Y200 for one male and one female household member. These subsidies will
cover  travel,  food,  and  lodging  expenses  for  the  beneficiaries  and  will  enable  them  to
travel to training centers at the township and county level, return home, and pay for their
living expenses for the duration of the training programs (two weeks). Training subsidies
for severely affected AP and fees (Y100 per student) will also be financed by LEPC.

E.

Institutional Responsibilities

8.
LEPC  as  the  Executing  Agency  has  overall  planning,  implementation  and
financial responsibilities. Municipal power supply companies (MPSC) will be responsible
for the implementation of the LARP at the local level including establishing agreements
with  township  governments,  delivery  of  compensation  funds,  and  internal  monitoring.
Township,  county,  and  village  governments  each  will  be  responsible  to  a  different
degree  for  land  redistribution  tasks,  asset  valuation,  consultation,  and  delivery  of
entitlements to the AP.

F.

Disclosure and Public Consultation

9. 
Preparation  of  the  LARP  was  based  on  an  intense  public  consultation  process
carried  out  through  surveys  and  community  meetings  and  involving  implementing
agencies,  local  governments,  and  AP.  An  information  booklet  summarizing  the  LARP

 57

Appendix 7, page 3

and compensation policy was distributed to all AP, and a Chinese version of the LARP
has been made available to the affected villages.

G.

Grievance Procedures

10. 
Grievance procedures are described in the LARP. Grievances will be first lodged
with the village committee. If within two weeks no settlement is reached, the complainant
may have one month to lodge the grievances to either LEPC, the relevant MPSC, or the
county  land  administration  office.  If  within  two  more  weeks  a  case  is  still  unresolved  it
can  be  further  moved  up  to  the  township  land  administration  office.  Final  appeal  is
available in the civil courts as established by the Regulations for Administrative Redress.

H.

Monitoring and Evaluation

11.
In collaboration with resettlement staff at the township and county level LEPC will
monitor  the  implementation  of  the  LARP  every  six  weeks.  External  monitoring  will  be
assigned to an independent agency. LEPC will report quarterly to ADB on the progress
of  land  acquisition,  resettlement,  and  compensation/rehabilitation  tasks.  External
monitoring  reports  will  be  sent  to  ADB  every  six  months.  The  performance  of  the
rehabilitation program will be periodically evaluated by an external monitoring agency for
four years after the beginning of the Project.

I.

Finances

The  cost  of  resettlement  and  land  acquisition  for  the  Project  is  estimated  at
12.
Y34.54  million  ($4.16  million).  This  comprises  compensation  for  assets,  including  land
and  resettlement;  income  restoration  assistance;  management  costs;  monitoring;  and
taxes. Annual adjustments to the cost estimates will be made based on the inflation rate
for the previous year.

FINANCIAL ANALYSIS OF THE PROJECT

1.
Detailed financial analysis was conducted on the Project. The assumptions used
in the financial evaluation are described below. All the costs are expressed in constant
2001 prices.

A. 

Benefits

The electricity sales projections are based on the load growth forecast prepared
2
by the Liaoning Electric Power Company (LEPC) with the assistance of its consultants,
the SP Power Economic Research Center, and the consultants for the preparation of the
project feasibility study. Electricity sales are projected to increase by 4.5 percent in 2001,
4.0 percent thereafter annually up to 2004, and 3.5 – 3.8 percent annually up to 2010.
Although the forecast electricity sales growth of 20-22 percent for the period 2001-2010
is  slightly  higher  than  the  sales  growth  for  1995-2000  (17  percent),  it  is  considered
reasonable taking account of the Asian economic crisis and the gross domestic product
growth predictions for the People’s Republic of China (PRC).

B.

Costs

 

1.

Capital Costs

3.
The capital costs include physical contingencies but exclude price contingencies
and interest charges during construction. The construction is assumed to be carried over
three years as 20 percent, 50 percent, and 30 percent, respectively.  The salvage value
at the end of 22 years is assumed to be 4 percent of capital costs.

2. 

Operation and Maintenance Costs

4.

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

The operation and maintenance (O&M) expenses are calculated in various parts.

Equipment  Maintenance.  As  per  regulatory  guidelines  in  the  PRC,  O&M
expenses  are  calculated  as  1.5  percent  per  annum  of  the  original  value  of
imported  equipment  and  as  2.5  percent  of  the  original  value  of  domestic
equipment.  In  this  analysis  a  figure  of  2  percent  is  used  as  an  estimate  for  the
O&M cost of the Project.

Material and Spare Parts. These are various consumables and spare parts that
are  required  to  maintain  equipment.  Based  on  past  statistics  an  estimate  of
Y0.001  per  kilowatt-hour  (kWh)1  is  used  to  forecast  this  component,  which  is
standard in PRC projects.

Salaries. Salaries of production, transmission, distribution, and management staff
are  calculated  on  the  basis  of  Y0.01/kWh1,  which  is  increased  by  another  14
percent as a provision for performance-related payments.

Income Tax and Value-Added Tax

8. 
 The Project’s taxable income is subject to 33 percent income tax and 17 percent
Value-Added  tax  (VAT)  on  operating  revenue.  A  7  percent  urban  construction  tax,  a  3
percent  educational  surcharge  on  VAT  sales,  and  a  1.7  percent  sales  tax  have  been
applied to the operating revenue. The domestic annual inflation rate has been projected
at  2  percent  for  2001-2005  and  4  percent  for  each  year  thereafter.  An  international
inflation rate of 2.4 percent a year has been applied.

5.

Weighted Average Cost of Capital

9. 
The  weighted  average  cost  of  capital  (WACC)  is  calculated  using  the  capital
asset  pricing  model  (CAPM)  method.  Detail  calculations  are  shown  below.  The  cost  of
equity  is  calculated  as  11.9  percent  using  a  nominal  risk  free  rate  of  5.5  percent,  an
equity  premium  of  6.5  percent,  and  a  debt  equity  ratio  of  60  percent.  Taking  the  tax
deductibility of interest payments into account, the post-tax nominal WACC is calculated
as 6.53 percent. Since the risk premium of 1.6 percent (the difference between local and
foreign  inflation  rates  of  4  percent  and  2.4  percent,  respectively)  was  added  to  the
foreign  exchange  interest  rate,  the  real  WACC  is  calculated  using  the  average  local
inflation  rate  of  3.6  percent.  This  results  in  a  2.82  percent  post-tax  real  WACC  for  the
Project (Table 1).

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS

A.

Least-Cost Analysis

1. 
 The least-cost generation expansion analysis covering 2000-2015 (the planning period)
for  the  Liaoning  Power  Grid  (LPG)  was  carried  out  by  State  Power  Economic  Research  Center
(SPERC)  using  the  GESP  II  model.1  The  input  data  and  assumptions  were  reviewed  by  the
consultants and found appropriate. The analysis used constant 2000 prices and a discount rate of
12  percent.  Tradable  commodities  were  valued  at  border  prices  at  the  prevailing  exchange  rate
(Y8.30/$1.00). Nontradable commodities were valued at shadow prices, using a mix of standard
and specific conversion factors.2 The methodology and presentation of shadow prices are detailed
in the report prepared by SPERC: Report on Shen-da Transmission Project.

The  least-cost  analyses  confirmed  the  robustness  of  the  proposed  Project.  The  Project
2.   
will still be required, even if the demand growths slow to the average consumption growth rates
of  3.6  percent  between  2000  and  2005,  3.2  percent  between  2005  and  2010,  and  2.5  percent
between  2010  and  2015  (low  growth  case  projected  by  the  consultants).  Two  least-cost
generation  expansion  alternatives  for  LPG  were  considered.  Alternative  I  is  the  basic  case,
which  is  to  construct  the  500  kilovolt  (kV)  transmission  line  and  grid  rehabilitation  to  transmit
electricity  from  the  northeastern  part  of  the  northeast  region  to  the  load  center  of  Dalian.  In
Alternative  II,  the  500  kV  transmission  line  and  grid  rehabilitation  will  not  be  constructed;
instead, a 600 megawatt (MW) thermal power plant in the load center is considered to meet the
load requirement. The present values of cost flows (discounted to 2000 prices) for Alternative I
and  II  are  Y159.75  billion  and  Y159.82  billion,  respectively.  The  results  indicate  that  the  least-
cost  generation  expansion  scenario  including  the  Project  compares  favorably  with  the  one
without  the  Project.  LPG  is  a  subgrid  of  the  Northeast  China  Power  System,  which  covers
Liaoning, Jilin, Heilongjiang and the eastern part of Inner Mongolia. A least-cost plan was also
undertaken for the Northeast China Power System, which demonstrated that the Project is part
of  the  least-cost  plan  for  the  Northeast  Power  System,  and  the  power  exports  from  the
northeastern part of the Northeast China Power System to Dalian were justified.3

3.   
The  result  of  the  least-cost  analysis  is  supported  by  an  equalizing  discount  rate  (EDR)
analysis,  in  which  the  Shen-da  transmission  line  replaces  thermal  power  generation  in  Dalian.
The analysis compares the investment and operation cost of the 500 kV transmission line and
grid rehabilitation with that of a 600 MW thermal power plant in Dalian. The main assumptions
for the candidates, including the fuel cost and capital cost, were the same as those used in the
least-cost analysis. Coal consumption, at 310 grams of coal equivalent per kilowatt-hour for new
600  MW  units,  compares  well  with  international  values.  The  capital  cost  of  a  coal-fired  power
plant is assumed to be $586 per kilowatt, based on the real capital costs of some recent projects
in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). Transmission and distribution losses are assumed at 8
percent of supply power from the northeastern part of the northeast region to Dalian, and annual
operation and maintenance (O&M) cost of transmission and distribution facilities is 2.0 percent
of capital investment cost. The economic life of the various project components was assumed to
be 25 years. The results of an environmental impact evaluation (Appendix 10) were incorporated

                  

1

2

3

The computer model GESP II (Generator of Electric System Planning) has been used for similar analysis in more
than 10 power projects financed by the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank.
A standard conversion factor of 0.93 was used. Border prices were used for all imported items. Local costs were
shadow priced using group and specific conversion factors: 1.0 for equipment, 1.51 for steel, 0.69 for cement, 0.63
for timber, 2.0 for skilled labor, and 0.67 for unskilled labor. Taxes and duties were excluded.
There  are  large  power  exchanges  between  the  LPG  grid  and  other  subgrids.  Liaoning  Province  is  a  net  power
importer. Historically, it has received hydroelectricity from Jilin Province and thermal power from Heilongjiang and
the eastern part of Inner Mongolia every year.

 63

Appendix 9, page 2

into  the  EDR  analysis.  The  costs  of  environmental  mitigation  measures  and  the  resettlement
program have been included in the project costs. Without environmental impact, the EDR shows
that the 500 kV transmission line and griid rehabilitation is superior up to a discount rate of 12.1
percent, compared with the alternative of locating the thermal plant in Dalian. If low unit values
for  national  environmental  impact  are  used,  the  EDR  will  be  19.7  percent.  The  levelized  unit
costs  show  that  the  unit  cost  of  producing  electricity  in  the  northeastern  part  of  the  northeast
region and sending it to Dalian (0.308 Y/kWh) is only about 0.3 percent lower than the cost of
producing electricity in Dalian (0.309 Y/kWh). However, if environmental impacts are taken into
account, the cost is 7.5 percent lower than that of the alternative (0.333 Y/kWh).

B.

Economic Internal Rate of Return

4.   
The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  calculations  include  (i)  the  500  kV
transmission line and grid rehabilitation components, (ii) the rural electrification component, and
(iii)  the  whole  Project.  No  separate  analysis  was  undertaken  for  the  competitive  power  market
development component and the closure of small, inefficient power plants component due to the
difficulties in quantifying benefits. However, the costs of these components were included in the
EIRR calculation of the whole Project.

5. 
As  in  the  least-cost  analysis,  the  economic  analysis  used  the  conversion  factors;,
investment  costs  for  generation,  transmission,  and  distribution;  fuel  costs;  and  O&M  costs,
where  applicable.  For  EIRR  calculations,  the  benefits  of  energy  output  were  valued  based  on
consumer's  willingness  to  pay  and  end-consumer  tariffs.  Transmission  and  distribution  losses
were  estimated  based  on  the  statistics  of  historical  loss  rates  in  the  Liaoning  Electric  Power
Company  Ltd.  (LEPC).  The  results  of  the  EIRR  analysis  for  the  500  kV  transmission  line  and
urban  grid  rehabilitation  components  show  efficiency  improvement  (reduced  losses)  and
increased supply as the major benefits. This conservative approach, which does not include the
benefit of improved quality of supply, yields an EIRR of 16.0 percent for the component (Table
1).  Similarly,  the  results  of  the  EIRR  analysis  for  the  rural  electrification  component  show
efficiency  improvement  (reduced  losses)  and  increased  supply  as  the  major  benefits.  This
calculation,  which  does  not  include  the  impact  on  the  rural  economic  development  and  other
benefit,  yields  an  EIRR  of  18.4  percent  for  the  component  (Table  2).  Finally,  the  EIRR  for  the
whole  Project,  which  includes  the  costs  for  the  competitive  power  market  development
component and the closure of small, inefficient power generation units, is 18.5 percent (Table 3).

C. 

Environmental Benefits

An  economic  evaluation  of  the  environmental  impacts  of  the  Project,  carried  out  based
6. 
on  the  benefits  transfer  method,    used  (i)  methodology  adopted  in  the  Asian  Development
Bank’s  Workbook  on  Economic  Evaluation  of  Environmental  Impacts  (1996)  to  determine
adjusted  estimate  of  the  monetary  damages  caused  by  air  pollution  during  the  study  period,
taking  into  account  the  location  of  the  power  plant,  the  emission  level,  and  the  population
affected; and (ii) estimates of average annual climate change for carbon emissions to evaluate
the  monetary  damages  caused  by  greenhouse  gas  emissions.  If  the  economic  cost  of  the
environmental  impacts  of  a  comparable  coal-fired  power  plant  in  Dalian  were  added  to  the
benefits  of  the  proposed  Project,  the  EIRR  for  the  for  the  500  kV  transmission  line  and  grid
rehabilitation  components  would  increase  to  17.9  percent  and  for  the  whole  Project,  to  24.9
percent.

                  

4

In this analysis, costs of environmental mitigation measures and the resettlement program have been included in the
Project estimates.

 D. 

Sensitivity Analysis

64

Appendix 9, page 3

7.
Sensitivity  analysis  shows  that  the  base  EIRR  of  18.5  percent  for  the  whole  Project
would  decrease  to  (i)  16.8  percent  if  the  Project  experiences  a  cost  overrun  of  10  percent;  (ii)
16.8  percent  if  the  project  benefits  are  reduced  by  10  percent;  (iii)  16.9  percent  if  the  Project
were to experience a commissioning delay of one year; and (iv) 13.7 percent if (i), (ii), and (iii)
happen.  In  addition,  if  willingness  to  pay  would  be  10  percent  below  expectation,  the  EIRR
would decrease to 17.7 percent. An assumed 20 percent lower loss reduction would reduce the
EIRR  to  17.5  percent  and  an  assumed  20  percent  depreciation  of  the  local  currency  would
reduce the EIRR to 17.8 percent.
