ECONOMIC ANALYSIS OF ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT

A. 

Introduction

1.
The  economic  analysis  of  environmental  impact  requires  an  evaluation  of  avoided
environmental costs of a project, which are taken as environmental benefits/costs of the project.
For  the  proposed  Project,  the  environmental  benefits  were  calculated  mainly  for  two
components: (i) the  Shen-Da 500  kilovolt (kV) transmission component, and (ii) the closure of
small  power  plants  component.  For  the  Shen-Da  500  kV  transmission  component,  two  cases
(with/without  the  Shen-Da  500  kV  transmission  line)  were  studied  to  identify  the  incremental
power  flow  of  the  proposed  transmission  line.  Based  on  the  incremental  power  flow,  the
differences  in  environmental  impacts  of  generation  in  Dalian  and  the  coal  mining  area  in  the
northeastern  part  of  the  northeast  region  were  taken  as  the  environmental  benefits  of  this
component.  For  the  component  involving  closure  of  small  power  plants,  the  alternative
generation  option  was  assumed  to  be  300  megawatt  (MW)  coal-fired  thermal.    The
environmental  benefit  from  the  closure  of  small  power  plants  was  the  reduced  emission  in
Liaoning Province. The environmental impact analysis is carried out in four steps:

(i)
(ii)
(iii)

(iv)

Step 1: major stressors or polluters were identified;
Step 2: impact screening was carried out for each stressor;
Step 3: if the impacts were major, effort was made to place monetary valuation;
and
Step  4:  the  benefits  (costs)  flows  were  quantified  for  integration  with  the
economic analysis of the Project.

B.

 Identification and Screening of Environmental Stressors

2.
Air  pollution  emissions  come  mainly  from  coal-fired  power  plants.  In  Step  2,  these
environmental stressors were screened for their potential impacts on four major aspects: human
health,  human  welfare,  environmental  resources,  and  global  systems.  Of  the  various  impacts,
the following major ones proved to be significant:

Human  Health  Impacts:  Increased  Morbidity  and  Mortality  from  Conventional  Air
3.
Emissions.  Health  studies  currently  focus  on  airborne  particles  that  are  small  enough  to  be
inhaled  deeply  into  the  lungs  (called  PM10).  PM10  aerosols  resulting  from  the  combustion  of
fossil fuels include sulfate and nitrate aerosols, acid aerosols, and other chemical constituents.
Their impacts include both premature mortality and chronic acute respiratory disease.

Human Welfare Impacts: Reduced Visibility and Materials Damage from Air Emissions

4.
of PM10, sulfur dioxide (SO2) and Nitrogen Oxides (NOx).

Visibility Impacts:  Particulate  matter  (less  than  2.5  micrometers  in  diameter)  that  is
emitted directly from industries or is formed in the presence of SO2 and NOx gas emissions can
reduce visual range.

Building  and  Materials  Impacts:  Particulate  matter  and  acid  deposition  from  SO2
emissions  can  damage  materials.    Materials  damage  can  include  surface  soiling,  surface
erosion,  blistering,  paint  discoloration,  corrosion  and  tarnishing  of  metals  and  electronic

 69

Appendix 10, page 2

components,  fading,  reduction  of  fabric  tensile  strength,  and  spalling  of  buildings  and
monuments.

6.
Global  Systems  Impact:  It  is  well  recognized  that  environmental  impacts  are  not
confined  to  the  immediate  location  or  within  country  limits  but  involve  impacts  on  the  global
level. The economic value of carbon dioxide was assessed using the estimates of the Workbook
on Economic Evaluation of Environmental Impacts.

C.

 Economic Assessment of Environmental Impacts

Once  the  major  environmental  impacts  and  their  influence  on  human  health,  human
7.
welfare,  and  socioeconomic  activities  are  properly  identified,  the  next  step  is  to  value  such
impacts economically. In Step 3, the environmental impact of the major environmental stressors
is  evaluated  in  three  ranges  in  terms  of  distances  to  the  plant  sites:  local  (within  30  kilometers
[km]), regional (beyond 30 km and within 100 km), and distant (beyond 100 km and within 500 km).

8.
Various methods are available for impact valuations, some of which require substantial
amounts  of  primary  data,  time,  and  field  investigations.  Thus  the  benefit  transfer  method  was
used  for  this  assessment,  which  allows  using  results  from  similar  valuations  conducted  in  the
different parts of the world with proper adjustments to any particular project. While adjusting the
data from the results of original research in the United States to the People’s Republic of China
(PRC),  three  major  adjustments  were  carried  out  for:  (i)  GDP  differentials  between  the  United
States and the PRC, (ii) updating price level to 2000 constant prices, and (iii) medical cost level
differentials between the United States and the PRC. For inflation adjustments, a GDP deflator
was  used.  Consistent  with  the  economic  life  of  the  proposed  project,  the  period  of
environmental impact is assumed to be 25 years (from 2004 to 2028).

9.
In  Step  4,  for  the  economic  valuation  of  environmental  impacts,  an  average  value  was
used.  Based  on  the  incremental  power  flow,  the  differences  of  environment  impacts  of
generation in Dalian and the coal mining area were taken as the environmental benefits of the
Shen-Da 500 kV transmission component. The generation of this power flow was assumed to
come  from  600  MW  coal-fired  thermal  power  plants  in  Dalian  and  the  coal  mining  area,
respectively. For the closure of small power plants component, the alternative generation option
of small power plants was assumed to be 300 MW coal-fired thermal in Liaoning Province.  The
environmental benefit derived by the closure of small power plants was the emission reduction
in Liaoning Province.

PROJECT RISK ANALYSIS

1.
To  complement  the  sensitivity  analysis  attached  in  Table  –  of  the  Report  and
Recommendation  to  the  President,  risk  analyses  have  been  performed  using  a  probabilistic
approach  to  the  perceived  risk  factors  that  affect  the  viability  of  the  Project.  Five  broad
categories of risk have been considered:

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

Demand  Risk.  Demand  risk  is  related  to  lower  electricity  demand  growth  than  forecast
and/or  breach  of  contract  by  the  purchaser.  Low  demand  growth  could  jeopardize  the
financial and economic viability of the Project. Lower than the expected demand growth
in  1999  and  2000  brought  substantial  losses  to  many  larger  power  projects  in  the
People’s Republic of China (PRC).

Price Risk. Price risk is related to changes in the willingness and ability of consumers to
pay for electricity. Recent experience in the PRC shows that the power producer could be
confronted with unexpected price changes in both inputs and outputs.

Project  Cost  Risk.  Higher  than  estimated  project  cost  usually  results  from  (a)  higher
equipment prices,1 or (b) exchange rate fluctuations. The major equipment and facilities
of  generation  will  be  purchased  through  international  competitive  bidding.  Prices  could
therefore  be  affected  by  market  fluctuations.  Depreciation  of  the  local  currency  would
result in a major cost increase of the Project. Though it has been stable for a long period
of time, there could be some risk of currency depreciation because of the PRC entrance
into the World Trade Organization.

Implementation  Risk.  Implementation  delays  during  construction  are  a  common
phenomenon for many infrastructure projects in the PRC.2 They are caused by a number
of  factors,  in  particular  loan  start-up  delay  (delay  in  loan  effectiveness),  delay  of
construction  due  to  interfacing  problems  among  different  suppliers,  unforeseen  site
conditions, and inadequate construction management.

(v) 

Operational  Performance  Risk.  Poor  operational  performance  could  be  caused  by  low
quality  of  generating  equipment  and  facilities,  inadequate  maintenance,  and/or  poor
management.

2.
The  risk  analysis  was  carried  out  for  the  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  to
ensure  the  economic  viability  of  the  Project.  Based  on  the  foregoing  considerations  and
sensitivity  analyses,  six  variables  for  EIRR  analysis  have  been  selected  as  the  crucial  risk
variables  because  of  their  significant  impact  on  the  Project  is  economic  viability.  The  risk
analysis  was  carried  out  using  the  Monte  Carlo  simulation  technique.3  The  inputs  for  the  risk
analysis  are  taken  from  the  base  case  benefit  analysis/cost.  The  correlation  between  risk
                                                       
1  There  have  been  substantial  loan  savings  in  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  assisted  projects.  As  of  end
September 2000, of the 45 ongoing projects, 17 had loan savings totaling about $800 million. Of this, about $330
million  had  been  canceled  in  consultation  with  ADB,  $300  million  is  under  discussion  for  cancellation  and  $170
million is estimated as potential savings. The total loan saving on these 17 projects account for about 30 percent of
the loan amounts originally approved for these projects, and about 13 percent of the total loan amounts for all the
ongoing  projects.  This  was  mainly  due  to  substantial  decline  in  equipment  prices  in  the  PRC  due  to  market
conditions. The decline in equipment prices has been taken into consideration in the cost estimates.

2  Delays  in  loan  effectiveness  often  lead  to  increases  in  the  payment  of  commitment  charges,  extensions  of  loan
closing  dates  and  delayed  attainment  of  project  benefits.  The  average  number  of  months  elapsed  from  loan
approval to loan effectiveness for PRC projects increased from 7.3 months in 1996 to 9.2 months at the end of 1999
and  further  to  9.8  months  as  of  30  September  2000  (the  ADB  wide  average  is  7.2  months).  Similarly,  the  time
elapsed from loan signing to effectiveness increased from 3.2 months in 1997 to 4.0 months as of September 2000
(the ADB-wide average is 3.8 months).

3  The  simulation  was  carried  out  using  the  Risk  Master  computer  software.  Monte  Carlo  simulation  works  by
generating  a  series  of  random  numbers  following  the  distribution  of  probability  of  each  risk  variable.  For  each
simulation, which represents a combination of different state of risk variables, EIRRs are calculated and recorded.
The results of 3,000 simulations are averaged.

 72

Appendix 11, page 2

variables is explicitly considered before the simulation to avoid generation of unrealistic project
scenarios. The probability distributions attached to the selected variables take into account past
Asian  Development  Bank  experience  in  power  projects  in  general  and  the  project/country
circumstances in particular. The six selected variables were capital cost, foreign exchange rate,
implementation  delay,  willingness-to-pay,  incremental  power  supply  and  line  loss  reduction
benefits, the assumed value ranges and the assumed probability distributions. The results were
based on 3,000 simulations.

3.
The  expected  EIRR,  based  on  the  weighted  average  of  all  simulated  combinations,  is
15.8 percent (with a standard deviation of 2.9 percent4), about 2.7 percent lower than the base
case  value  without  consideration  of  project  risks.  The  probability  for  the  EIRR  to  be  below  12
percent is about 11 percent (cumulative distribution of EIRR).

A  careful  load  forecast  for  the  demand  growth  in  Dalian  was  carried  out.  The  demand  for
4.
power is forecast to be lacking in Dalian, and the Liaoning Electric Power Company Ltd (LEPC) will
have  no major  problems  in  transmitting  the  surplus  power  in  the  northeastern  part  of  the  northeast
region,  even  in  the  case  of  moderate  economic  growth  in  Dalian.  All  proposed  technologies  are
currently  in  successful  use  in  the  PRC.  Cost  overrun  risks  will  be  addressed  by  appropriate
procurement  actions;  contract  packages  for  major  components  will  be  defined  before  loan
negotiations.  The  risk  of  delay  in  project  construction  due  to  project  management  shortcomings  is
minimal because of the experience gained during the implementation of the Northeast China Power
Transmission  Project,5  the  timely  staffing  and  training  of  personnel  of  LEPC,  and  the  assistance
provided by experienced international engineering consultants.
 
The  Government  and  ADB  are  currently  going  through  necessary  steps  for  better
5.
coordination  in  the  approval  processes  to  solve  the  problem  of  loan  start  up  delay.6  In  view  of
advanced  preparatory  work,  risks  associated  with  project  construction,  cost  overruns,  and
implementation delays are within reasonable limits and manageable with the agreed supervision and
involvement of competent consultants. Particular attention will be given to the safety aspects of the
Project, and to the capabilities and performance of major contractors. All the above analyses clearly
show  that  the  Project  is  robust  under  future  uncertainties  and  that  the  risks  associated  with  it  are
acceptable.

                                                       
4    A  common  statistical  indicator  of  the  risk  of  a  project  is  the  standard  deviation,  which  measures  the  dispersion
around the expected value. The greater this variability, the less confident one can be of the outcomes associated
with the project. The standard deviation of 2.9 indicates that in general, this Project is a low-risk one.
